Abnormal increased number of megaloblasts in the bone marrow. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of an abnormal number of fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormality of histiocytes, in which the cells take on a sea blue appearance due to abnormally increased lipid content. Histiocytes are a type of macrophage. Sea-blue histiocytes are typically large macrophages from 20 to 60 micrometers in diameter with a single eccentric nucleus whose cytoplasm if packed with sea-blue or blue-green granules when stained with Wright-Giemsa. [HPO:probinson, PMID:8797061]

Phenotype: Reduced lymphocyte surface expression of CD43
Def: A reduction in the expression of CD43 on the cell surface of lymphocytes. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood associated with a reduced concentration of ketone bodies. [HPO:probinson]

Decreased fetal activity associated with multiple joint contractures, facial anomalies and pulmonary hypoplasia. Ultrasound examination may reveal polyhydramnios, ankylosis, scalp edema, and decreased chest movements (reflecting pulmonary hypoplasia). [HPO:probinson]

An inability of the tubules in the kidney to reabsorb small molecules, causing increased urinary loss of electrolytes (sodium, potassium, bicarbonate), minerals, glucose, amino acids, and water. [HPO:probinson]
Longstanding metabolic acidosis. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15882309]
Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale. [PMID:19152422]
Accentuated, prominent philtral ridges giving rise to an exaggerated groove in the midline between the nasal base and upper vermillion border. [PMID:19152422]
Bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline. [PMID:19125436]

A facial appearance characteristic of a fetus or neonate due to oligohydramnios experienced in the womb, comprising ocular hypertelorism, low-set ears, receding chin, and flattening of the nose. [HPO:probinson]
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. [HPO:probinson, PMID:26770271]
A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter. [HPO:probinson]

Pyloric stenosis, also known as infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, is an uncommon condition in infants characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. Clinically infants are well at birth. Then, at 3 to 6 weeks of age, the infants present with projectile vomiting, potentially leading to dehydration and weight loss. [HPO:probinson, PMID:32310391]
Congenital absence of the anus, i.e., the opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal narrowing of the anal opening. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of chronic diarrhea, which is usually taken to mean diarrhea that has persisted for over 4 weeks. [HPO:probinson]
An inadequate sucking reflex, resulting in the difficult of newborns to be breast-fed. [HPO:pnrobinson]
The presence of a hernia in which the upper part of the stomach, i.e., mainly the gastric cardia protrudes through the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus. [HPO:probinson]
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition). [HPO:probinson]
Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the lower portion of the esophagus. [HPO:probinson]
A pathological narrowing of the esophagus that is caused by the development of a ring of scar tissue that constricts the esophageal lumen. [HPO:probinson]

A condition in which there is increased production of gastrin by a gastrin-secreting tumor (usually located in the pancreas, duodenum, or abdominal lymph nodes) that stimulates the gastric mucosa to maximal activity, with consequent gastrointestinal mucosal ulceration. [HPO:probinson]
The inability to maintain a comfortable body temperature in warm or hot weather. [HPO:probinson]

Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by a rapid increase in temperature to 39-42 degrees C in response to inhalational anesthetics such as halothane or to muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. [HPO:curators]
Atrophy of the cortex of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
A type of renal tubular acidosis characterized by a failure of the proximal tubular cells to reabsorb bicarbonate, leading to urinary bicarbonate wasting and subsequent acidemia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Curved linear dimple below the lower lip

Def: Forward protrusion of the glabella. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125436]

A facial appearance characteristic of myopathic conditions. The face appears expressionless with sunken cheeks, bilateral ptosis, and inability to elevate the corners of the mouth, due to muscle weakness. [HPO:curators]

Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement). [HPO:probinson]
A kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities. [HPO:probinson]

Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the neuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11406682]

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible. [HPO:probinson, HPO:zaferyueksel, UKB:tklockgether]

A type of migraine in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed, but may accompany or occur in the absence of, the headache. The symptoms of an aura may include fully reversible visual, sensory, and speech symptoms but not motor weakness. Visual symptoms may include flickering lights, spots and lines and/or loss of vision and/or unilateral sensory symptoms such as paresthesias or numbness. At least one of the symptoms of an aura develops gradually over 5 or more minutes and/or different symptoms occur in succession. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15304572]

A type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor. That is, an oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger). [HPO:probinson, PMID:16344298]

Repeated headache attacks lasting 4-72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1) unilateral location, 2) pulsating quality, 3) moderate or severe pain intensity, and 4) aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs. Headache attacks are commonly accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15304572]

A type of encephalocele (that is, a a protrusion of part of the cranial contents including brain tissue through a congenital opening in the cranium, typically covered with skin or mucous membrane) in the occipital region of the skull. Occipital encephalocele presents as a midline swelling over the occipital bone. It is usually covered with normal full-thickness scalp. [DDD:awilkie, HPO:probinson]

A functional defect characterized by reduced total lung capacity (TLC) not associated with abnormalities of expiratory airflow or airway resistance. Spirometrically, a restrictive defect is defined as FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) less than 80 per cent. Restrictive lung disease may be caused by alterations in lung parenchyma or because of a disease of the pleura, chest wall, or neuromuscular apparatus. [NIHR:ldaugherty, PMID:28194273]

Increased susceptibility to aspiration pneumonia, defined as pneumonia due to breathing in foreign material, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonia. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the pleura. [HPO:sdoelken]
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs. [HPO:probinson]
Persistent abnormal dilatation of the bronchi owing to localized and irreversible destruction and widening of the large airways. [HPO:probinson]
Any structural anomaly that affects the upper motor neuron. []
Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days. [HPO:probinson]
A cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, filled with cerebrospinal fluid, that communicates directly with the ventricular system. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9279052]
The presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia. [HPO:curators]
Hemorrhage occurring between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. [HPO:sdoelken]

During normal embryological development, the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of L1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column. The filum terminale is a slender, threadlike structure that remains after the normal regression of the distal embryonic spinal cord and attaches the spinal cord to the coccyx. A tethered cord results if there is a thickened rope-like filum terminale which anchors the cord at the level of L2 or below, potentially causing neurologic signs owing to abnormal tension on the spinal cord. [HPO:curators]
An abnormally high level of uric acid in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of proteins in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An abnormally increased potassium concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of homocystine in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of heparan sulfates in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of homocystine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of lysine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:4696900]
Hair on the neck extends more inferiorly than usual. [PMID:19125436]
Inward advance of skin over the nail plate. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal pattern of speech in which the words are as if measured or scanned; there is a pause after every syllable, and the syllables themselves are pronounced slowly. [PMID:16247074]

A tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling; imbalance. The retropulsion test is widely regarded as the gold standard to evaluate postural instability, Use of the retropulsion test includes a rapid balance perturbation in the backward direction, and the number of balance correcting steps (or total absence thereof) is used to rate the degree of postural instability. Healthy subjects correct such perturbations with either one or two large steps, or without taking any steps, hinging rapidly at the hips while swinging the arms forward as a counterweight. In patients with balance impairment, balance correcting steps are often too small, forcing patients to take more than two steps. Taking three or more steps is generally considered to be abnormal, and taking more than five steps is regarded as being clearly abnormal. Markedly affected patients continue to step backward without ever regaining their balance and must be caught by the examiner (this would be called true retropulsion). Even more severely affected patients fail to correct entirely, and fall backward like a pushed toy soldier, without taking any corrective steps. [PMID:25613349]
Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds. [HPO:probinson]
Pathological protein aggregates formed by hyperphosphorylation of a microtubule-associated protein known as tau, causing it to aggregate in an insoluble form. [HPO:sdoelken]
Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20. [HPO:probinson]
Delayed myelination in the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
A cyst occurring within the choroid plexus within a cerebral ventricle. [HPO:probinson]
Individuals with Pseudobulbar signs often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc. [HPO:sdoelken]
Defective development of the vermis of cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]
Inability to move the muscles of respiration. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations

Def: Hair shafts are rough in texture. [HPO:probinson]
A triangular depigmented region of white hairs located in the anterior midline of the scalp. [DDD:probinson]
Hair that is fine or thin to the touch. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced number or density of axillary hair. [HPO:probinson]
Hypopigmented hair that appears silver-gray. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of axillary hair. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the eyebrow. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced number or density of pubic hair. [HPO:probinson]
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyebrow. [HPO:probinson]
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes. [DDD:cmoss]
Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body. [HPO:curators]
Sparseness of the body hair. [HPO:probinson]
Loss of scalp hair at an earlier than normal age. [HPO:probinson]
Uncombable hair. [HPO:probinson]
Upward and/or sideward growth of anterior hair. [PMID:19125436]
Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract. [HPO:probinson]
Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum. [HPO:probinson]
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
The vomiting of blood. [HPO:probinson]

The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of multiple diverticula of the colon. [HPO:probinson]
Repeated episodes of diarrhea separated by periods without diarrhea. []
More pronounced paramedian peaks and median notch of the Cupid's bow. [PMID:19125428]
An exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus, or a quick movement near the face. [HPO:curators]
A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes. [HPO:probinson]

Increase in size of the cisterna magna, one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata. [HPO:probinson]
Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size. [HPO:sdoelken]
A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected. [DDD:cmoss]
Progressive loss of hair. [HPO:probinson]
Loss of all hair on the entire body. [HPO:probinson]
Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas. [PMID:19125436]
Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth. [HPO:curators]
Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15202698]
Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
Def: Deterioration of the tissues of the lateral corticospinal tracts. [HPO:probinson]

A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness. [HPO:probinson]

Repeated episodes of headache with rapid onset, reaching a peak within minutes and of short duration (less than one hour) with pain that is throbbing, pulsating, or bursting in quality. [HPO:probinson]
Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital absence of the vermis of cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]

Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness. [HPO:probinson]
Moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 35-49. [HPO:curators]
A form of hydrocephalus characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure upon lumbar puncture. [eMedicine:1135286, HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability to walk (ambulate). [HPO:probinson]

A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument. [HPO:probinson]
Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the brainstem. [HPO:probinson]
Any structural anomaly of the lower motor neuron. [HPO:probinson]
Visual perceptions that are not elicited by a corresponding stimulus from the outside world. []

Lack of observable abnormal electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns in an individual with a history of seizures. About half of individuals with epilepsy show interictal epileptiform discharges upon the first investigation. The yield can be increased by repeated studies, sleep studies, or by ambulatory EEG recordings over 24 hours. Normal interictal EEG is a sign that can be useful in the differential diagnosis. []
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the hand. []

If the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid-filled space or cavum is present. The cavum septum pellucidum is present at birth but usually obliterates by the age of 3 to 6 months. It is up to 1cm in width and the walls are parallel. It is an enclosed space and is not part of the ventricular system or connected with the subarachnoid space. [HPO:curators]
The presence of complexes of repetitive spikes and waves in EEG. [HPO:jalbers]

A type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb (i.e., it gives way in little, repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched). [HPO:probinson]

No consensus exists on what a stroke-like episode is, but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit, occurring with or without the context of seizures, which last longer than 24 hours. [PMID:22715346, PMID:23907585]

The patient stands with the feet placed together and balance and is asked to close his or her eyes. A loss of balance upon eye closure is a positive Romberg sign and is interpreted as indicating a deficit in proprioception. [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the superior cerebellar peduncle. [HPO:probinson]
An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the brain. []

Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum. [HPO:curators]

Cerebral cysts, usually located in the wall of the caudate nucleus or in the caudothalamic groove. They are found in up to 5.2% of all neonates, using transfontanellar ultrasound in the first days of life. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12423490]

An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth. [HPO:probinson, PMID:14657304]
Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting. [HPO:probinson]

Long-tract signs refer to symptoms that are attributable to the involvement of the long fiber tracts in the spinal cord, which connect the spinal cord to the brain and mediate spinal and motor functions. []
A defect in the motor ability that enables speech. [HPO:curators]
Impairment of expressive language and relative preservation of receptive language abilities. That is, the patient understands language (speech, writing) but cannot express it. [HPO:probinson]
A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic. [DDD:probinson]
The presence of a hamartoma of the hypothalamus. [HPO:curators]
Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus
Def: The presence, on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, of markedly low signal intensity of the globus pallidus that surrounds a central region of high signal intensity in the anteromedial globus pallidus, producing an eye-of-the-tiger appearance. The sign is thought to represent iron accumulation in the globus pallidus. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11110959, PMID:19881070, PMID:29371252]

Phenotype: Dense calcifications in the cerebellar dentate nucleus

Def: A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality. [HPO:probinson]
Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid. [HPO:curators]
Spasticity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve. []

Abnormality of REM sleep. Phases of REM sleep are characterized by desynchronized EEG patterns, increases in heart rate and blood pressure, sympathetic activation, and a profound loss of muscle tonus except for the eye and middle-ear muscles. There are then phases of rapid eye movements. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Calcification of the small brain vessels
Def: Deposition of calcium salts within small blood vessels of the brain. [HPO:probinson]
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum. [HPO:sdoelken]
A type of holoprosencephaly in which the left and right frontal and parietal lobes are fused and the interhemispheric fissure is only present posteriorly. [gc:hpe]

A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord. [HPO:probinson]
Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs. [HPO:probinson]

A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads. [HPO:probinson]

Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, for instance in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture in that joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients usually have difficulties standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase (in the German language literature this is referred to as Duchenne sign). Similar gait patterns can be caused by orthopedic conditions when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. [PMID:27770207]
An increase of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid. [HPO:probinson]
Fleeting perceptual experiences that occur during the transition from wakefulness to sleep. [PMID:27358492]

Hypsarrhythmia is abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes. There is continuous (during wakefulness), high-amplitude (>200 Hz), generalized polymorphic slowing with no organized background and multifocal spikes demonstrated by electroencephalography (EEG). [HPO:curators]
A sudden and transient episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone, often triggered by emotions. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21931493, PMID:22249574]
Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. Nonword repetition (NWR) is a measure of short-term phonological memory. [HPO:probinson]
Electron-dense granules within double membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles. [PMID:22073234]

Phenotype: Neuronal loss in central nervous system

Def: A type of dystonia that affects the midline muscles, i.e., the chest, abdominal, and back muscles. [HPO:probinson]
Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs. [HPO:probinson]
Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus. [HPO:probinson]
A form of torticollis in which the head is drawn back, either due to a permanent contractures of neck extensor muscles, or to a spasmodic contracture. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17917462]

Phenotype: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter
Def: Patchy loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Parkinsonism with favorable response to dopaminergic medication
Def: Parkinsonism is a clinical syndrome that is a feature of a number of different diseases, including Parkinson disease itself, other neurodegenerative diseases such as progressive supranuclear palsy, and as a side-effect of some neuroleptic medications. Some but not all individuals with Parkinsonism show responsiveness to dopaminergic medication defined as a substantial reduction of amelioration of the component signs of Parkinsonism (including mainly tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability) upon administration of dopaminergic medication. []

Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. The test for nonword repetition involves the repetition of nonsensical words of increasing length and complexity and is regarded as a measure of phonological (speech sound) processing and short-term memory [PMID:19646677]
Developmental dysplasia of the hair. [HPO:probinson]
Increased height of the central portion of the eyebrow, forming a crescent, semicircular, or inverted U shape. [PMID:19125427]
Absence of pubic hair. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the nipple. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of more than two nipples. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital failure to develop, and absence of, the nipple. []
Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that forms a non-compliant shell around the heart, and resulting from chronic inflammation of the pericardium. [HPO:probinson]
Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats. [HPO:probinson]

A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus. [HPO:probinson]
Paroxysmal, recurrent episodes of vomiting. [HPO:curators]
The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus. [DDD:hfirth]
An intermittent form of abdominal pain. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased strength of the muscle layer of stomach, which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue. [HPO:probinson]

Atrophic gastritis (AG) is a histopathological entity that is characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa with loss of gastric glandular cells and replacement by intestinal-type epithelium, pyloric-type glands, and fibrous tissue. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21483628]
Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force. [HPO:probinson]
An erosion of the mucous membrane in a portion of the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat. [HPO:probinson]
An ulcer, that is, an erosion of an area of the gastric mucous membrane. [HPO:probinson]
Angiectasia of lymph vessels (i.e., dilatation of lymphatic vessels) in the intestines. [HPO:probinson]
Hypoplasia of the pancreas. [HPO:probinson]
A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Paresis of extensor muscles of the big toe

Def: Telangiectasia affecting the gastrointestinal tract. [HPO:probinson]

Celiac disease (CD) is an autoimmune condition affecting the small intestine, triggered by the ingestion of gluten, the protein fraction of wheat, barley, and rye. Clinical manifestations of CD are highly variable and include both gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal features. The hallmark of CD is an immune-mediated enteropathy. This term is included because the occurence of CD is seen as a feature of a number of other diseases. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23681421]
The presence of fibrosis of that part of the liver with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]
Progressive destruction of the small-to-medium bile ducts of the intrahepatic biliary tree, which leads to progressive cholestasis and often end-stage liver disease. [HPO:probinson]
A type of hepatic necrosis that is concentrated around the necrosis of hepatocytes localized around the intrahepatic branch of portal vein. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic root. []

An overriding aorta is a congenital heart defect where the aorta is positioned directly over a ventricular septal defect, instead of over the left ventricle. The result is that the aorta receives some blood from the right ventricle, which reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood. It is one of the four conditions of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The aortic root can be displaced toward the front (anteriorly) or directly above the septal defect, but it is always abnormally located to the right of the root of the pulmonary artery. The degree of override is quite variable, with 5-95% of the valve being connected to the right ventricle. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Venous varicosities of celiac and mesenteric vessels
Def: Elongated and tortuous mesenteric veins, which comprise the inferior mesenteric vein and the superior mesenteric vein. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Right aortic arch with mirror image branching
Def: The aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus and not the left mainstem bronchus, but does not result in the creation of a vascular ring. The first branch is the left brachiocephalic artery which divides into the left carotid artery and left subclavian artery, the second branch is the right carotid artery, the third branch is the right subclavian artery. [DDD:dbrown, HPO:sdoelken]

In type IV atherosclerotic lesions a dense accumulation of extracellular lipid occupies an extensive but well-defined region of the intima. This type of extracellular lipid accumulation is known as the lipid core. A fibrous tissue increase is not a feature, and complications such as defects of the lesion surface and thrombosis are not present. The type IV lesion is also known as atheroma. Type IV is the first lesion considered advanced in this classification because of the severe intimal disorganization caused by the lipid core. The characteristic core appears to develop from an increase and the consequent confluence of the small isolated pools of extracellular lipid that characterize type III lesions. The increase in lipid is believed to result from continued insudation from the plasma. Type IV lesions, when they first appear in younger people, are found in the same locations as adaptive intimal thickenings of the eccentric type. Thus, atheroma is, at least initially, an eccentric lesion. [PMID:7648691]
Inflammation of a superficial vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein). [HPO:probinson]

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow at any level from the small hepatic veins to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with the right atrium, 1 and occurs in 1/100,000 of the general population worldwide. The most common presentation is with ascites, but can range from fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) to asymptomatic forms. Obstruction of hepatic venous outflow is mainly caused by primary intravascular thrombosis, which can occur suddenly or be repeated over time, accompanied by some revascularization, accounting for the variable parenchymal hepatic damage and histologic presentation. Budd-Chiari syndrome is thus a disease, but since it occurs as a manifestation of several other diseases, this term is kept for the present for convenience. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16265183]

Phenotype: Arteriovenous fistulas of celiac and mesenteric vessels

Def: The presence of extra bones within a cranial suture. Wormian bones are irregular isolated bones which appear in addition to the usual centers of ossification of the cranium. [HPO:probinson]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to bone. []
A disorder of bone growth affecting the vertebrae and the ends of the long bones (epiphyses). [HPO:probinson]
An increased tendency to fractures following trauma, with fractures occurring without pain. [HPO:curators]
The presence of a nephroblastoma, which is a neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children. [HPO:probinson]

A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor. [HPO:probinson]
Trilobar skull configuration when viewed from the front or behind. [PMID:19125436, PMID:29089832]
An abnormal narrowing of the foramen magnum. [HPO:probinson]

A deformity of the sella turcica whereby the sella extends further anterior than normal such that the anterior clinoid process appears to overhang it, giving the appearance of the letter J on imaging of the skull. [HPO:pnrobinson]
Increased width of the skull. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of an abnormally thick calvaria. [HPO:curators]
Aplasia of frontal sinus. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal enlargement of the sella turcica. [HPO:probinson]

A developmental malformation of the occipital bone and upper end of the cervical spine, in which the latter appears to have pushed the floor of the occipital bone upward such that there is an abnormal flattening of the skull base. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of symmetrical and circular openings (foramina) in the parietal bone ranging in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters wide. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increase in the size of the foramen magnum. [HPO:curators]
The presence of a high and narrow palate. [HPO:curators]
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the palate. [HPO:curators]
Unusual prominence of the median palatal raphe, which is the ridge formed by the fusion of the two plates of the skull that form the hard palate. [HPO:curators]
A depression located at an oral commissure. [HPO:sdoelken, PMID:19125428]
Increased depth of the median tongue furrow. [HPO:probinson]
A morphological abnormality of the mouth in which the angle of the mouth is downturned. The oral commissures are positioned inferior to the midline labial fissure. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125428]

Phenotype: Absence of bactericidal oxidative respiratory burst in phagocytes
Def: An absence of the phase of elevated metabolic activity, during which oxygen consumption increases, that occurs in neutrophils, monocytes, and macrophages shortly after phagocytosing material. An enhanced uptake of oxygen leads to the production, by an NADH dependent system, of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), superoxide anions and hydroxyl radicals, which play a part in microbiocidal activity. [GO:0045728]
An increased susceptibility to Aspergillus infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of Aspergillus infections. [HPO:probinson]

A chronic, relapsing, inflammatory, and often febrile multisystemic disorder of connective tissue, characterized principally by involvement of the skin, joints, kidneys, and serosal membranes. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Staphylococcus aureus infection. [HPO:probinson]
Lymphadenopathy (enlargement of lymph nodes) owing to hyperplasia of follicular (germinal) centers. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23281438]
A chronic form of lymphadenopathy that is not related to infection. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the lymph nodes. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of frontal sinus. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to infections with Escherichia coli, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to Serratia marcescens infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Serratia marcescens infection. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to Klebsiella infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Klebsiella infection. [HPO:probinson]
Cleft lip and cleft palate affecting both sides of the face. [HPO:probinson]
A thickened white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17944749]

Osteomalacia is a general term for bone weakness owing to a defect in mineralization of the protein framework known as osteoid. This defective mineralization is mainly caused by lack in vitamin D. Osteomalacia in children is known as rickets. [HPO:curators]

A pathologic fracture occurs when a bone breaks in an area that is weakened secondarily to another disease process such as tumor, infection, and certain inherited bone disorders. A pathologic fracture can occur without a degree of trauma required to cause fracture in healthy bone. [HPO:curators]
Joint hypermobility (ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion) affecting many or all joints of the body. [HPO:curators]
Punctate (speckled, dot-like) deposition of calcium of calcium salts in the articular cartilage (cartilage located in joints). [HPO:probinson, PMID:29246349]
Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the tracheal tissues. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18663210]

An abnormal reduction on the vital capacity, which is defined as the total lung capacity (volume of air in the lungs at maximal inflation) less the residual volume (i.e., volume of air in the lungs following maximal exhalation) of the lung. [HPO:probinson]
Multiple congenital contractures in different body areas. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23050160]
Coxa vara includes all forms of decrease of the femoral neck shaft angle (the angle between the neck and the shaft of the femur) to less than 120 degrees. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased extension of the knee joint, so that the knee can bend backwards. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9580896]
The presence of a tail-like skin appendage located adjacent to the sacrum. [HPO:probinson]

An anomalous radiographic appearance of the developing pelvis, in which the greater ischiadic noth (incisura ischiadica major) is shallow and the pelvis takes on the appearance said to resemble a halberd (a weapon especially of the 15th and 16th centuries consisting typically of a battle-ax and pike mounted on a handle). [HPO:probinson, PMID:19232556]

Disseminated multifocal hemangiomatous or lymphangiomatous lesions of the skeleton. The lesions are lytic, well-defined, round or oval lesions within the medullary cavity, and they have an intact cortex, and manifest variable peripheral sclerosis and may exhibit endosteal scalloping. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11930062]
Inspiration of a foreign object into the airway. [HPO:probinson]
Eversion of the posterior bladder wall through the congenitally absent lower anterior abdominal wall and anterior bladder wall. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23650202]
Abnormal function of a sphincter of the urinary bladder. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of a lymph node. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to infections with Burkholderia cepacia, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent. [HPO:probinson]
Impaired production of memory cells, the B cells that persist for years or an entire lifetime and which confer rapid and enhanced response to secondary challenge. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of normal overall immunoglobulin levels with deficiency of specific immunoglobulins directed against bacterial polysaccharides. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Absence of lymph node germinal center
Def: Absence of germinal centers in lymph nodes. Germinal centers are the parts of lymph nodes in which B lymphocytes proliferate, differentiate, mutate through somatic hypermutation and class switch during antibody responses. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin M (IgM) in blood. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Elevated proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cells
Def: An abnormally increased proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative (double negative or DN) alpha-beta regulatory T cells (Tregs) as compared to total number of T cells. []

Phenotype: Increased proportion of HLA DR+ T cells
Def: An elevated proportion of T cells that express human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DR. HLA-DR is an MHC class II cell surface receptor that presents antigens (peptides of at least 9 amino acids), thereby constituting a ligand for the T-cell receptor. HLA-DR can be upregulated in response to immune stimulation. [PMID:11531958]
The presence of a medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the ilium ala. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased width of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally). [HPO:probinson]
Widening of the ilium ala, that is of the wing of the ilium, combined with external rotation, leading to a flared appearance of the iliac wing. [HPO:probinson, PMID:28744080]

A condition characterized by obstruction of the airway and by pauses in breathing during sleep occurring many times during the night. Obstructive sleep apnea is related to a relaxation of muscle tone (which normally occurs during sleep) leading to partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway with resultant obstruction of the air flow. [HPO:probinson]
Apnea resulting from depression of the respiratory centers in the medulla oblongata. There is a lack of respiratory effort rather than obstruction of airflow. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Apneic episodes precipitated by illness, fatigue, stress
Def: Recurrent episodes of apnea that are precipitated by factors such as illness, fatigue, or stress. [HPO:curators]
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [PMID:29763022]
Episodes of very rapid breathing. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal reduction in alveolar ventilation occuring during sleep. This is characterized by a rise in arterial carbon dioxide. [PMID:20308760]
A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally increased variability of the size of the vertebral bodies. [HPO:probinson]
Recurrent bouts of sudden, severe apnea that may be life-threatening. [HPO:probinson]

A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates from immature liver precursor cells and macroscopically is composed of tissue resembling fetal or mature liver cells or bile ducts. [eMedicine:986802, HPO:probinson]

A tumor that develops in the retrostyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, arising from an island of paraganglion tissue derived from the neural crest that is located on the vagus nerve. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17268589]
The presence of an ependymoma of the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a leiomyosarcoma of the uterus. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]
A benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause hyperparathyroidism. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased phosphate concentration in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
Microscopic hematuria detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine. [HPO:sdoelken]
An increased concentration of all types of amino acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the blood. [HPO:probinson, PMID:26101005]
An increased concentration of chloride in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally decreased magnesium concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased magnesium concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal reduction in the concentration of corticotropin, also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of protein in the cerebrospinal fluid. [KI:phemming, PMID:29114301]
The presence in the serum of an autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in the blood circulation. [DDD:spark]
An increased concentration of histidine in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18901181, PMID:20240447]

Phenotype: Decreased activity of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex

Def: Reduced sensitivity of end organs to thyroid hormone characterized by elevated serum levels of free thyroid hormone with nonsuppressed thyroid stimulating hormone. [DDD:spark, PMID:24847459]
A reduction in aldehyde oxidase level. [HPO:probinson]
Ventral hernia refers to a condition in which abdominal contents protrude through a weakened portion of the abdominal wall. [HPO:probinson, HPO:skoehler]
An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region. [HPO:probinson]
Exaggerated convexity of the cervical vertebral column, causing the cervical spine to bow outwards and take on a rounded appearance. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital absence of a part of the vermis of cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]
Altered immune function characterized by lymphoid proliferation, immune activation, and excessive autoreactivity often leading to autoimmune/inflammatory complications. [PMID:26233425]
An impairment of the class-switch recombination process that normally leads B lymphocytes to produce IgG, IgA, or IgE. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11544001]
Selective deficiency of one or more, but not all, classes of immunoglobulins. [HPO:probinson]
Inability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal positioning in which the elbows are turned out. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Absent microvilli on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes
Def: Absence of the fingerlike protrusive, actin-dependent structures found on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes. [PMID:15130947]
Decreased ability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test. [HPO:probinson]
A bending or abnormal curvature of the radius. [HPO:probinson]
An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the fibula. [HPO:probinson]
Prolongation of the time taken for a standardized skin cut of fixed depth and length to stop bleeding. [DDD:mumford]
A morphological abnormality of epiphyses whereby they are abnormally outwardly curving (protuberant). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Bowing of limbs due to multiple fractures
Def: Curvature of the shafts of the long bones due to multiple fractures. [HPO:curators]
Bending of the diaphysis (shaft) of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the radius and the humerus. [HPO:sdoelken]
Chronic reduction in active and passive mobility of the shoulder joint due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement. [HPO:probinson]
Amelia of all four limbs. [HPO:sdoelken]
Underdevelopment of the patella. [HPO:curators]
Reduced ability to extend (straighten) the knee joint. []

An anomaly related to partial closure, or failure of development of the ulnar side of the distal radial growth plate, which results in an arrest of epiphyseal growth of the medial and volar portions of the distal radius. This leads to shortening of the radius and relative overgrowth of the ulna. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12362035]
Reduction in the concentration of albumin in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of glucose in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti]

Phenotype: Defective DNA repair after ultraviolet radiation damage

Def: An increased concentration of 4-hydroxy-L-proline in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Disproportionately long fibulae. [HPO:probinson]
Small hands and feet. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22286749]

Phenotype: Hypoplasia of the capital femoral epiphysis
Def: Underdevelopment of the proximal epiphysis of the femur. [HPO:probinson]
Trophic changes occurring in a limb. [HPO:probinson]

Limitation of the extension of the hip, i.e., decreased ability to straighten the hip joint and thereby increase the angle between torso and thigh; moving the thigh or top of the pelvis backward. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal shortening of the femur. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increase in the carrying angle, which is the angle he long axis of the extended forearm as it lies lateral to the long axis of the arm. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18506557]

Phenotype: Protuberances at ends of long bones
Def: The presence of multiple protuberances (bulges, or knobs) at the ends of the long bones. [HPO:probinson]

Loss of bone mass occurring beneath the periosteum (the periosteum is the connective-tissue membrane that surrounds all bones except at the articular surfaces). This process may create a serrated and lace-like appearance in periosteal cortical bone. [PMID:24849102]
An increased concentration of glycine in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:18901181, PMID:20240447]
An increased excretion of phosphates in the urine. [HPO:curators]
An abnormally decreased chloride concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]

Reduced activity of coagulation factor VIII. Factor VIII (fVIII) is a cofactor in the intrinsic clotting cascade that is activated to fVIIIa in the presence of minute quantities of thrombin. fVIIIa acts as a receptor, for factors IXa and X. [HPO:probinson]
Excretion in urine of proteins of a size smaller than albumin (molecular weight 69 kD). [PMID:95574]
An abnormally decreased calcium concentration in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of cystine in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of proline in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased amount of nitrogen in the form of urea in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]

A reduction in the circulating levels of all the major classes of immunoglobulin. is characterized by profound decreases in all classes of immunoglobulin with an absence of circulating B lymphocytes. [PMID:23726535]

Phenotype: T-wave inversion in the right precordial leads

Def: An elevated concentration of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A increased concentration of serotonin in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased concentration of adenosylcobalamin. Adenosylcobalamin is one of the active forms of vitamin B12. [HPO:probinson]
An decreased concentration of cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An abnormally high level of uric acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti]
An elevated urinary concentration of cystathionine. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increased in the concentration of corticotropin, also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally low urinary specific gravity, i.e., reduced concentration of solutes in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Increased excretion of oxalates in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of pyruvic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of 5-aminolevulinic acid (CHEBI:17549) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increased concentration of parathyroid hormone. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of taurine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of carnosine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

An increased level of a dibasic amino acid in the urine. Dibasic amino acids are usually refered to simply as basic aminoacids because they contain basic side chains at neutral pH. These are arginine (Arg), lysine (Lys), and histidine (His). []
A shift from the normally round (convex) appearance of the iliac wing towards a square-like appearance. [HPO:probinson]
Intrapelvic bulging of the medial acetabular wall. [HPO:probinson]

Flattening of the superior part of the acetabulum, which is a cup-shaped cavity at the base of the hipbone into which the ball-shaped head of the femur fits. The acetabular roof thereby appears horizontal rather than arched, as it normally does. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally increased width of the pubic symphysis is the midline cartilaginous joint uniting the superior rami of the left and right pubic bones. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability to move the femur outward to the side. [HPO:probinson]

The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a reduction in the height of the notch. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of nipples that instead of pointing outward are retracted inwards. [HPO:sdoelken]
Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased length from the nasal root to the nasal base. [PMID:19152422]
The presence of a notch in the margin of the ala nasi. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19152422]
It is characterized by one or more symptoms including sneezing, itching, nasal congestion, and rhinorrhea. [PMID:11449200]
Decreased superior-inferior length of the nasal bridge, which is the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose. []

Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations below the mean, or alternatively, an apparently decreased length from the nasal root to the nasal tip. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19152422]

An abnormal appearance of muscle fibers observed on muscle biopsy. Ragged red fibers can be visualized with Gomori trichrome staining as irregular and intensely red subsarcolemmal zones, whereas the normal myofibrils are green. The margins of affect fibers appear red and ragged. The ragged-red is due to the accumulation of abnormal mitochondria below the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber, leading to the appearance of a red rim and speckled sarcoplasm. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12075011, PMID:16537564]

In the NBT test, neutrophils change the colorless compound NBT into a compound with a deep blue color. If this test is negative (i.e., no blue color is produced), then this indicates a defect in superoxide-generating NADPH oxidase activity with inability to efficiently kill phagocytized bacteria. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Fingerprint intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
Def: An intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material in a trabecular or fingerprint-like pattern. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased rate of pyruvate carboxylase activity. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of Krebs cycle metabolism that is characterized by a decreased rate of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase activity. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Deficient excision of UV-induced pyrimidine dimers in DNA
Prolonged G2 phase of cell cycle

Def: A diffuse form of amyloidosis. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of glutamine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:4696900]
An increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine. [HPO:gcarlotti]
An increased concentration of ethylmalonic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Chromosomal breakage induced by crosslinking agents
Def: Increased amount of chromosomal breaks in cultured blood lymphocytes or other cells induced by treatment with DNA cross-linking agents such as diepoxybutane and mitomycin C. [HPO:sdoelken]
Decreased concentration of methylcobalamin. Methylcobalamin is a form of vitamin B12. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased cellular sensitivity to UV light

Def: Decreased activity of coagulation factor V. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Rectilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
Def: An intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material in a straight or rectilinear pattern. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of tyrosine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An decreased concentration of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of methionine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased level of phosphoethanolamine (synonym: O-phosphoethanolamine) in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23093139]
Abnormally elevated level of the enzyme phosphoribosyl pyrophosphatesynthetase, which catalyzes the synthesis of PP-ribose-P from ATP and ribose-5-phosphate. [PMID:4200723]
Location of the urethral opening on the inferior aspect of the penis. [HPO:curators]
Increased size of the ridge of tissue that extends along the midline of the scrotum. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Gonadal tissue inappropriate for external genitalia or chromosomal sex

Def: An increased amount of creatinine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of hydroxyproline in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
The presence in serum of antibodies against smooth muscle. [HPO:probinson]
A type of hyperbilirubinemia with neonatal onset. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal decrease in orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase level. [HPO:gcarletti]
A increased concentration of arginine in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18901181, PMID:20240447]
Underdeveloped acetabulae. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced side to side width of the pelvis. [HPO:probinson]
A benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface of the pelvis. Exostoses are capped by cartilage, and arise from a bone that develops from cartilage. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally squared appearance of the bony pelvis, a normally rounded or basin-shaped structure. [HPO:probinson]
Widening of the femoral head and neck. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of ferritin in the blood circulation. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of cystathionine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:16902722]
A decreased concentration of leptin in the blood. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16932309]
An increased concentration of threonine in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18901181, PMID:20240447]
An increased concentration of lysine in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18901181, PMID:20240447]
Spondylolysis is an osseous defect of the pars interarticularis, thought to be a developmental or acquired stress fracture secondary to chronic low-grade trauma. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20440613]
Congenital synostosis between two or more adjacent vertebrae (partial or complete fusion of adjacent vertabral bodies). [HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability to move the vertebral column with a resulting limitation of neck and trunk flexion. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11601420, PMID:2246660]
Developmental hypoplasia of the dens of the axis. [HPO:probinson]

A butterfly vertebra (sagittal cleft vertebra or anterior rachischisis) is a sagittal defect in the vertebral body caused by failure of fusion of the two lateral chondrification centers during embryogenesis. The name is based on the appearance of the two hemivertebrae emerging as butterfly wings from the central cleft on x-ray. [HPO:probinson, PMID:31448202, PMID:3693103]
A partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joints. [HPO:curators]
Generalized weakness or decreased strength of the muscles, affecting both distal and proximal musculature. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced strength of the axial musculature (i.e., of the muscles of the head and neck, spine, and ribs). [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Hair shafts flattened at irregular intervals and twisted through 180 degrees about their axes

Def: An abnormal increase in catecholamine concentration in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

The prothrombin consumption test measures the formation of intrinsic thromboplastin by determining the residual serum prothrombin after blood clotting is complete. If there is a defect in the process, less prothrombin will be converted to thrombin than normal (less prothrombin is consumed). This test may be abnormal with conditions including deficiency of factors VIII or IX, with circulating anticoagulants, thrombocytopenia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Focal necrosis of right ventricular muscle cells

Def: A type of megaloblastic anemia that improves upon administration of pyrimidine supplements such as uridylic acid and cytidylic acid. [HPO:probinson]
The formation of bullae (blisters) with cleavage in the lamina lucida layer of the skin. [HPO:probinson]

Reduced level of the enzyme glutathione synthetase, which catalyzes the last step in the synthesis of glutathione and a deficiency results in low levels of glutathione. Acidosis is due to reduced feedback inhibition of gamma-glutamyl cysteine synthetase in the gamma-glutamyl cycle, which ultimately leads to overproduction and accumulation of 5-oxoproline. [PMID:17397529]
An abnormally increased level of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric acid in the urine. [PMID:19177531]
An increased concentration of noradrenaline in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Normal peripheral blood lymphocytes, when stimulated by phytohemagglutinin (PHA) are cytotoxic for homologous and heterologous cells but not for autologous cells in monolayer culture. The cytotoxic effect is thought to be indicative of the immunological competence of the lymphocytes. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of alanine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:16902722, PMID:4696900]
A reduction in the rate of cholesterol esterification. [HPO:probinson, PMID:3378364]
An decreased level of renin in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Endopolyploidy on chromosome studies of bone marrow
Def: An increase in the number of chromosome sets per cell in bone marrow cells. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of amino acid metabolism characterized by a decreased level of propionyl-CoA carboxylase. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of threonine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the level of thymic horomone. [PMID:7058086]
Decreased concentration of sulfate in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of tryptophan in the urine. [HPO:gcarletti, PMID:18901181]
An increase in the amount of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
A left-right reversal (or \mirror reflection\") of the anatomical location of the viscera of the abdomen." [HPO:probinson]
Joint pain affecting the hip. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal flattening of the proximal epiphysis of the femur. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Enlargement of the proximal femoral epiphysis
Def: An abnormal enlargement of the proximal epiphysis of the femur. [HPO:probinson]
A narrowing of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium. [HPO:pnrobinson]

An abnormal gait pattern that arises from weakness of the pretibial and peroneal muscles due to a lower motor neuron lesion. Affected patients have footdrop and are unable to dorsiflex and evert the foot. The leg is lifted high on walking so that the toes clear the ground, and there may be a slapping noise when the foot strikes the ground again. [HPO:probinson, PMID:27770207]
A pattern of simultaneous degeneration and regeneration of axons (see comment). [HPO:probinson]
Atrophic changes of axons of the peripheral nervous system. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
Def: A reduced number of large myelinated nerve fibers. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to fatigue. [HPO:probinson]
An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves. [HPO:curators]
A phenomenon whereby patients are not able to stand up without the use of the hands owing to weakness of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. [HPO:probinson]
Wasting of thenar muscles, which are located on palm of the hand at the base of the thumb. []

Dilated, glial-lined cavity in spinal cord. This cavity does not communicate with the central canal, and usually is between the dorsal columns unilaterally or bilaterally along the side of the cord. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Generalized hypotonia due to defect at the neuromuscular junction

Def: A type of onion bulb formation prominently affecting the area of the basal lamina. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: EMG: decremental response of compound muscle action potential to repetitive nerve stimulation
Def: A compound muscle action potential (CMAP) is a type of electromyography (EMG). CMAP refers to a group of almost simultaneous action potentials from several muscle fibers in the same area evoked by stimulation of the supplying motor nerve and are recorded as one multipeaked summated action potential. This abnormality refers to a greater than normal decrease in the amplitude during the course of the investigation. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Distal sensory impairment of all modalities
Def: Reduced ability to sense pain, temperature, touch, vibration stimuli in the distal regions of the extremities. []
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the proximal metaphysis of the femur. []
Frontal schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies. [HPO:probinson]
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the lower back. []
A type of decreased nerve conduction velocity that affects the motor neuron. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal prolongation of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can normally be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the size of nerve terminals. [HPO:probinson]
Evidence of chronic denervation on electromyography. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system. [DDD:probinson]
Reduced speed of conduction of the action potential along a sensory nerve. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased rate of premature chromosome condensation
Def: An increased rate of premature chromosome condensation. [HPO:probinson]
The presence in the serum of autoantibodies directed against thrombocytes. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Low urinary cyclic AMP response to PTH administration

Def: The presence of abnormal electromyographic patterns indicative of myopathy, such as small-short polyphasic motor unit potentials. [HPO:curators]
A heterogeneous increase in IgM immunoglobulins characterized by a diffuse band on serum electrophoresis. [PMID:11508831]
Undetectable serum immunoglobulin A level at a value < 5 mg/dL (0.05 g/L). [HPO:probinson]
Excretion of peptides conjugated to sialic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the extraneuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11406682]

Phenotype: Paradoxical increased cortisol secretion on dexamethasone suppression test

Def: Abnormally increased movement at the junction between the first cervical (atlas) and the second cervical (axis) vertebrae as a result of either a bony or ligamentous anomaly. [HPO:probinson]
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths. Dysmyelination is distinguished from demyleination where there is destruction or damage of previously normal myelination. [HPO:probinson]
Hyperexcitability of the neuromuscular system related to abnormally low level of calcium in the blood, resulting in carpopedal or generalized spasms. [HPO:probinson]
A segmental pattern of demyelination and regeneration (remyelination) affecting peripheral nerves. [HPO:probinson]

Upturning of the big toe (and sometimes fanning of the other toes) in response to stimulation of the sole of the foot. If the Babinski sign is present it can indicate damage to the corticospinal tract. [HPO:curators]
An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the urine. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate. [HPO:probinson]
An elevated concentration of a gonadotropin hormone (stimulating hormone or luteinizing hormone) in the urine, consistent with the diagnosis of primary hypogonadism. []
Cellular accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. [PMID:30524313]
A mild degree of short stature, more than -2 SD but not more than -3 SD from mean corrected for age and sex. [DDD:hfirth]
A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Reduced ratio of renal calcium clearance to creatinine clearance
Def: A reduction of the ratio of renal calcium clearance to creatinine clearance to below 0.01. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Deficiency or absence of cytochrome b(-245)

Def: A reduction in methionine synthase activity. [HPO:probins]
Formation of crystals owing to an increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Parathormone-independent increased renal tubular calcium reabsorption
Def: An increase in the reabsorption of calcium by the renal tubulus that is not associated with increased parathormone levels. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23802516]
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased concentration of ornithine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased level of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH). ALDH and alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) are the primary enzymes involved in alcohol metabolism. [PMID:17718394]
An abnormal reduction in xanthine dehydrogenase level. [HPO:probinson]
An increased amount of 3-methylglutaconic acid in the urine. []
An abnormality of Krebs cycle metabolism that is characterized by a decreased rate of fumarate hydratase activity. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally low level of uric acid in the blood. [HPO:curators]
An increased level of iduronate-2-sulfatase activity in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of pyruvate in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]

The shoulder, or pectoral, girdle is composed of the clavicles and the scapulae. Shoulder-girdle weakness refers to lack of strength of the muscles attaching to these bones, that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Subsarcolemmal accumulations of abnormally shaped mitochondria
Def: An abnormally increased number of mitochondria in the cytoplasma adjacent to the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane), whereby the mitochondria also possess an abnormal morphology. [HPO:probinson]
Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system, affecting mainly the legs. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability to climb stairs. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 2 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy. [HPO:probinson]

Fiber splitting or branching is a common finding in human and rat skeletal muscle pathology. Fiber splitting refers to longitudinal halving of the complete fiber, while branching originates from a regenerating end of a necrotic fiber as invaginations of the sarcolemma. In fiber branching, one end of the fiber remains intact as a single entity, while the other end has several branches. [PMID:6123177]

Phenotype: Increased variability in muscle fiber diameter
Def: An abnormally high degree of muscle fiber size variation. This phenotypic feature can be observed upon muscle biopsy. [HPO:curators]
Rhabdomyolysis induced by a viral infection. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a folate sensitive fragile site at chromosome Xq28. [HPO:probinson]

An increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The ESR is a test that measures the distance that erythrocytes have fallen after one hour in a vertical column of anticoagulated blood under the influence of gravity. The ESR is a nonspecific finding. An elevation may indicate inflammation or may be caused by any condition that elevates fibrinogen. [PMID:10524488]
An increased concentration of prostaglandin E2 in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased level of glucose-6-phosphate isomerase. [HPO:gcarletti]
Absence of molybdenum cofactor(2-), a cofactor for enzymes including sulfite oxidase, xanthine oxidoreductase, and aldehyde oxidase. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of proprionic acid in the blood circulation. [PMID:22593918]
A decreased concentration of citrulline in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
Increased concentration of total (conjugated and unconjugated) bilirubin in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

A positive response to the regitine blocking test consisting of a substantial reduction in blood pressure following administration of regitine, indicative of the presence of increased levels of epinephrine and norepinephrine in the circulation, which is seen in pheochromocytoma-associated hypertension. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the cytosol. [HPO:gcarletti]
Lack of urothione (the urinary metabolite of molybdenum cofactor) in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:6960353]
Increased concentration of 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Foam cells with lamellar inclusion bodies
Def: The presence of foam cells that contain lamellar inclusion bodies. [HPO:probinson]
Increased cytoplasmic staining of fibroblasts with toluidine blue. [HPO:probinson, PMID:4195824]
If positive, the ferric chloride test indicates an increased concentration of phenols in the urine or blood. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of trimethylamine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital lack of development of the muscles, which are then replaced by a mixture of dense fat and fibrous tissue. [HPO:probinson, Neuromics:vstraub]
An abnormal reduction in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase level. [HPO:curators]
An increased concentration of adrenaline in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of foam cells, a type of macrophage that localizes to fatty deposits on blood vessel walls, in the central nervous system. []

Abnormal transferrin isoform profile consistent with a type I congenital disorder of glycosylation. In the traditional nomenclature for congenital disorders of glycosylation, absence of entire glycans was designated type I, and loss of one or more monosaccharides as type II. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15105360, PMID:22516080]
Abnormally reduced sulfite oxidase level. [HPO:probinson]

Increased time to coagulation in the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) test, a measure of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways. Phospholipid, and activator, and calcium are mixed into an anticoagulated plasma sample, and the time is measured until a thrombus forms. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally increased concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A deficiency of the electron transfer flavoprotein-ubiquinone oxidoreductase. [PMID:2989828]
An increased concentration of lactic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Recurring episodes of myoglobinuria, i.e., of the presence of myoglobin in the urine. This is usually a consequence of rhabdomyolysis, i.e., of the destruction of muscle tissue. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal reduction in dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (NADP+) level. [HPO:gcarletti]
An abnormality of glycoprotein metabolism related to a decreased level of alpha-1,6-mannosylglycoprotein 2-beta-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase activity. [HPO:gcarletti]
Reduced level of the enzyme beta-glucosidase, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucosylceramide into ceramide and glucose. []
A decreased concentration of methionine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]

Phenotype: Amyotrophy of the musculature of the pelvis
Def: Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the pelvis. [HPO:curators]

An abnormality in which the nuclei of sarcomeres take on an abnormally central localization (or in which this feature is found in an increased proportion of muscle cells). [HPO:probinson, PMID:20181480]
An abnormally reduced activity of the enzyme cytochrome C oxidase in muscle tissue. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of multiple deletions of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal protrusion of the scapula away from the surface of the back. [HPO:probinson]
Lack of strength of the proximal musculature occurring late in the clinical course. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger. [HPO:curators]
Muscular atrophy in the distribution of shoulder girdle and peroneal muscles. [HPO:probinson]
Enlargement of the muscles of the calf due to their replacement by connective tissue or fat. [HPO:probinson]
