Abnormal cell death involving muscle fibers usually associated with break in, or absence of, muscle surface fiber membrane and resulting in irreversible damage to muscle fibers. [HPO:curators]
Myofibrillar structural changes characterized by abnormal intracellular accumulation of the intermediate filament desmin and other proteins. [HPO:probinson]
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle tissue in a generalized (not localized) distribution. [HPO:curators]
Weakness of the muscles involved in neck flexion (sternocleidomastoid, longus capitus, longus colli, and scalenus anterior). [HPO:curators]
Amyotrophy affecting the muscles of the shoulder girdle. [HPO:curators]
Spontaneous, repetitive electrical activity demonstrated by electromyography (EMG). [HPO:probinson]
Weakness of the quadriceps muscle (that is, of the muscle fasciculus of quadriceps femoris). [HPO:curators]
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the thighs. [HPO:probinson]

The lysosomal-vacuolar pathway has a role in the controlled intracellular digestion of macromolecules such as protein complexes and organelles. This feature refers to the presence of an abnormally increased number of autophagic vacuoles in muscle tissue. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17027858]
The occurrence of an unusually high amount of muscle pain following exercise. [HPO:probinson]
Myotonia that occurs after a period of rest and decreases with continuing exercise. [HPO:probinson, PMID:7678441]
Recurrent episodes of muscle flaccidity, a type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Type 1 fibers relatively smaller than type 2 fibers
Def: The presence of abnormal muscle fiber size such that type 1 fibers are smaller than type 2 fibers. [HPO:curators]
Congenital underdevelopment of lymph vessels. [HPO:probinson]
Mechanical percussion (i.e., striking a muscle with a reflex hammer) leads to spreading waves of muscle contractions that begin proximally and spread laterally across the muscle. [HPO:probinson]
Formation of calcium deposits in any soft tissue. [HPO:probinson]
A malformation of the uterus in which the uterus is present as a paired organ as a result of the failure of fusion of the mullerian ducts during embryogenesis. [HPO:probinson]

Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep, but also can occcur while the affected individual is awake. [HPO:sdoelken, PMID:29926505]
A skin abnormality characterized by redness and irritation, with thick, red skin that displays flaky, silver-white patches (scales). [HPO:probinson]

A degree of kidney failure severe enough to require dialysis or kidney transplantation for survival characterized by a severe reduction in glomerular filtration rate (less than 15 ml/min/1.73 m2) and other manifestations including increased serum creatinine. [HPO:probinson]
Pili (from Latin pilus, hair) torti (from Latin tortus, twisted) refers to short and brittle hairs that appear flattened and twisted when viewed through a microscope. [HPO:probinson]
A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more). [HPO:probinson]
Decreased concentration of homovanillic acid (HVA) in the cerebrospinal fluid. HVA is a metabolite of dopamine. [KI:phemming, PMID:12615172]

Phenotype: Type 1 and type 2 muscle fiber minicore regions
Def: Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in type 1 and type 2 muscle fibers. [HPO:probinson]

Nemaline rods are abnormal bodies that can occur in skeletal muscle fibers. The rods can be observed on histological analysis of muscle biopsy tissue or upon electron microscopy, where they appear either as extensions of sarcomeric Z-lines, in random array without obvious attachment to Z-lines (often in areas devoid of sarcomeres) or in large clusters localized at the sarcolemma or intermyofibrillar spaces. [HPO:curators, PMID:11333380]
An abnormal predominance of type I muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy). [HPO:probinson]

Presence of abnormal vacuoles (membrane-bound organelles) in the sarcolemma. On histological staining with hematoxylin and eosin, rimmed vacuoles are popcorn-like clear vacuoles with a densely blue rim. The vacuoles are often associated with cytoplasmic and occasionally intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally reduced amount of adipose tissue in the thoracic cavity. []
A partial dislocation of the shoulder joint. [HPO:curators]
Formation of calcified tissue in the soft tissues surrounding the shoulder. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Sclerosis with transverse striations in metaphyses of the upper limbs

Def: Missing humerus bone associated with congenital failure of development. [HPO:probinson]
Clefting affecting the humerus. [HPO:curators]
A bending or abnormal curvature of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]

Presence of more than one exostosis originating in one or noth humerus bones. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage. [HPO:probinson]
Destruction of an area of humerus bone due to a disease process, such as cancer. []
Reduction in diameter of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]
Lack of formation of bone in the epiphysis of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Advanced ossification of the humeral epiphysis
Def: Ossification of the humeral epiphysis at an earlier age than normal. [HPO:probinson]
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the humeral epiphysis. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the humeral epiphysis. [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the humeral epiphysis. [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the humeral epiphyseal growth plate. [HPO:probinson]

Fracture or fragmentation at the lateral portion of the metaphysis of a long bone. The radiographic appearance is that of a small corner of metaphysis separated from the metaphyseal edge by thin linear radiolucency. This feature can be observed in child abuse but fragmented appearance of the metaphysis or facture-like lesions can also be detected in the setting of certain skeletal dysplasias. [PMID:15206413, PMID:20544318]

Phenotype: Cortical subperiosteal resorption of humeral metaphyses

Def: Flaring (increase of width with a splayed appearance) of the humeral metaphysis. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Lytic defects of the humeral metaphysis
Sclerotic humeral metaphysis with longitudinal striations

Def: An abnormal irregularity of the cortical surface of the diaphysis (shaft) of the humerus. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Ground glass opacity of humeral diaphysis
Periosteal new bone of humeral diaphysis

Def: Increased width of the humeral diaphysis. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the ulna and the humerus. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Narrow joint spaces of the elbow
Irregular articular surfaces of the elbow joints

Def: A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones that are part of the elbow. [HPO:probinson]
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis at the distal end of the humerus (at the elbow). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Sclerotic foci of metaphyses of the elbow

Def: A descriptive term for a forearm bone that appears to have an additional bone within it on radiography. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Cortical thickening of the forearm bones

Def: Missing ulna bone associated with congenital failure of development. [HPO:probinson]
Increased length of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
Osteosclerosis (increased density related to increased bone mass) of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
Reduction in diameter of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
An injury of the wrist with displacement of any of the eight carpal bones. [HPO:probinson]
The distal epiphysis (rounded portion of bone at the far end of the radius distal to the growth plate) has an abnormal cone-shaped appearance. []
Abnormal increase in width of the epiphyseal growth plate of the radius. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of the radius. [HPO:probinson]
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis of the radius. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Irregular ossification of the radial metaphysis
Sclerotic radial metaphysis with longitudinal striations

Def: Increase in width (breadth) of the radial metaphysis. [HPO:probinson]
Increase in width of the diaphysis of radius. [HPO:probinson]
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
A sloped configuration of the metaphysis (shaft) of the ulna. [HPO:curators]
Increase in width (breadth) of the ulnar metaphysis. [HPO:probinson]
The total absence of the hand, with no bony elements distal to the radius or ulna. [PMID:19125433]

Phenotype: Advanced ossification of the hand bones
Def: Ossification of hand bones at an earlier age than normal. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Delayed ossification of the hand bones
Def: Ossification of hand bones is less advanced than would be expected according to age-adjusted norms. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Dysharmonic maturation of the hand bones
Def: Pattern of hand-wrist development does not fit the normal sequence of ossification of the individual bones of the hand. [HPO:probinson]
Fusion of the hands and feet by a thin membrane of skin (scarring) seen in forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and leading to a \mitten\" hand deformity." [HPO:probinson, PMID:20301304]
Wrist is bent inward toward the thumb because of a congenital defect associated with shortening or absence of the radius. [HPO:probinson, PMID:28603568]

A hand in which the fingers are of nearly equal length and deflected at the first interphalangeal joint, so as to give a forklike shape consisting of separation of the first and second as well as the third and fourth digits. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal groove on the midline of the nose that may extend to the nasal tip. [HPO:sdoelken]
An abnormal indentation of the skin in the region of the nasal tip. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Short distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
Def: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the distal phalanx of the third finger. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Short middle phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Hypoplastic/small middle phalanx of the fifth finger. [HPO:skoehler, PMID:18494372]

Phenotype: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the little finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the little finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Curved distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Curved appearance of the distal phalanx of the 5th (little) finger. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Short distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Hypoplastic/small distal phalanx of the fifth finger. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Subluxation of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the little finger
Def: A partial dislocation of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the little finger. [HPO:sdoelken]
Ossification of carpal bones at an abnormally early age. [HPO:probinson]

The bone-in-bone sign is a radiographic finding produced by increased sclerosis (abnormally dense bone) occurring intermittently with zones of relatively normal bone density. This term should be used to describe such a finding in the carpal bones. [HPO:curators]
Carpal bones with irregular or fragmented margins. [HPO:probinson]
Point-shaped (punctate) calcifications affecting the carpal bones. [HPO:curators]
Formation of bone tissue of scaphoid is less than expected for age. [HPO:sdoelken]
Underdevelopment of the scaphoid. [HPO:probinson]
Osseous fusion of the lunate and triquetrum. [PMID:23853014]
Formation of bone tissue of trapezium is less than expected for age. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the trapezium. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Delayed ossification of the trapezoid bone
Def: Formation of bone tissue of trapezoid is less than expected for age. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the trapezoid. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Narrow small joints of the hand
Subluxation of the small joints of the hand
Def: A partial dislocation of some or all of the small joints of the hand. [HPO:curators]
Abnormal formation of new bone on the surface of a bone of the hand. [HPO:curators]
Short palm. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125433]

For children from birth to 4 years of age, the palm width is more than 2 SD below the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is below the 5th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately narrow for its length. [PMID:19125433]

Phenotype: Sclerosis of hand bones with transverse striations

Def: Fusion of the second metacarpal-trapezoid. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally reduced levels of aldosterone. [DDD:spark, HPO:probinson]
Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease. [HPO:probinson]

The presence of foam cells in the bone marrow, generally demonstrated by bone-marrow aspiration or biopsy. Foam cells have a vacuolated appearance due to the presence of complex lipid deposits, giving them a foamy or soap-suds appearance. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10932274]
Abnormality of an amino acid metabolic process. [HPO:probinson]

Abnormally reduced concentration of a purine compound. Purine compounds are aromatic heterocyclic compounds containing a purine moiety, which is formed a pyrimidine-ring ring fused to an imidazole ring. []
A pathological narrowing in the region above the aortic valve associated with restricted left ventricular outflow. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the left side of the heart. May include atresia of the aortic or mitral orifice and hypoplasia of the ascending aorta. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22192721]

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with a short pulmonary trunk arises from the truncus arteriosus, giving rise to both pulmonary arteries. [DDD:dbrown, HPO:probinson]
A colon of abnormally small caliber. [PMID:3484569]

A functional rather than mechanical obstruction of the intestines, associated with manifestations that resemble those caused by an intestinal obstruction, including distension, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea, in an individual in whom a mechanical blockage has been excluded. [HPO:probinson]
A kind of congenital defect of the anterior abdominal wall in which the intestines are evident through the thin, lax, and protruding abdominal wall in affected infants. [HPO:probinson]
A deficiency in the intake of energy and nutrients. []
A reduced desire to eat. []
Congenital atresia of the pylorus. [HPO:probinson]
Obstruction of the intestine due to abnormally thick meconium. [HPO:probinson]
Positioning of the nasal septum to the right or left in contrast to the normal midline position of the nasal septum. [HPO:probinson]

Intermittent claudication is a symptom of peripheral arterial occlusive disease. After having walked over a distance which is individually characteristic, the patients experience pain or cramps in the calves, feet or thighs which typically subsides on standing still. [PMID:27770207]
Repeated episodes of inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein). [HPO:probinson]
The formation of a blood clot inside an artery. [HPO:probinson]
A narrowing of the biparietal diameter (i.e., of the transverse distance between the protuberances of the two parietal bones of the skull). [HPO:curators]

Cranium bifidum occultum, also known as Catlin mark, is a congenital midline skull defect presenting as an enlarged posterior fontanelle in the upper posterior angle of the parietal bone close to the intersection of the sagittal and lambdoid sutures.1, 2, 3 Cranium bifidum occultum occurs due to a defect in intramembranous ossification, a process through which skull bones (frontal, parietal, squamous temporal and occipital bones superior to the mendosal suture) ossify under a vascularized membrane toward the midline to cover the brain.1, 4, 5 Unlike cranium bifidum cysticum, cranium bifidum occultum does not have herniation of intracranial contents. As the skull grows, the midline cranium bifidum occultum defect is separated into bilateral enlarged parietal foramina (EPF) by a midline osseous bridge. [PMID:28522383]
A forehead with abnormal flatness. [HPO:probinson]

This is a description previously used to describe a facial form characterized by a short, upturned nose, wide mouth, widely spaced eyes, and full cheeks. Because of the imprecision in this definition it is preferable to describe these features precisely. This term is retained because it was often used in the past, but it should not be used for new annotations. [HPO:probinson]
A type of primary immune deficiency that is characterized by a more severe defect in both the T- and B-lymphocyte systems. [HPO:curators]
A lasting absence of total IgG and total IgA and total IgM in the blood circulation, whereby at most trace quantities can be measured. [HPO:probinson]

Deficiency of secretory IgA (polymers of 2-4 IgA monomers are linked by two additional chains) and is the primary antibody response at the mucosal level, where it forms immune complexes with pathogens and allergens. [HPO:probinson, PMID:2251975]
A reduced level of the complement component C8 in circulation. [PMID:8098723]
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the frontal bone. [HPO:probinson]
A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the sagittal suture. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of erythrocytes with a mouth-shaped (stoma) area of central pallor on peripheral blood smear. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16304353]
A groove of the skin immediately in front of the ear. [HPO:probinson]
A rudimentary tag of ear tissue often containing a core of cartilage and located just in back of the auricle (outer part of the ear). [HPO:probinson]
A condition in which the superior portion of the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a dilated inner part of external acoustic meatus. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Exostosis of the external auditory canal
Def: A benign bony growth projecting outward from a bone surface within the external auditory canal. [HPO:probinson]
Pits in the earlobes at the location where ears are typically pierced for earrings. [PMID:6958333]
Lack of measurable response to stimulation of auditory evoked potentials. [HPO:probinson]
Benign congenital lesion of the postauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit. [HPO:sdoelken]
Small indentation anterior to the insertion of the ear. [HPO:sdoelken, PMID:19152421]
Chronic inflammation of the bronchi. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital defect in the occipital region of the skull, covered by skin of the scalp and containing meninges or remnants of glial or neural tissues. [HPO:probinson]
Hyperostosis (bony overgrowth) of the mandible. [HPO:probinson]
The anterior fontanelle generally ossifies by around the 18th month of life. A persistent open anterior fontanelle is diagnosed if closure is delayed beyond this age. [HPO:probinson]
The progressive development of an abnormally large skull. [HPO:probinson]

A relatively mild degree of macrocephaly in which the head circumference is not above two standard deviations from the mean, but appears dysproportionately large when other factors such as body stature are taken into account. [HPO:curators]
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull and the face. [HPO:curators]
Stagnation of head growth seen as flattening of the head circumference curve. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormality of head shape characterized by the presence of a short, wide head as well as a pointy or conical form of the top of the head owing to premature closure of the coronal and lambdoid sutures. [HPO:curators]
The presence of an abnormally large skull with onset at birth. [HPO:probinson]
Excessive growth of the calvaria. [HPO:probinson]
An enlargement of the posterior fontanelle relative to age-dependent norms. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased width of the cranial fontanelles and sutures. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Chronic rhinitis due to narrow nasal airway

Def: Increased length of the hairs of the eyebrows. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced or lacking hair growth in the temporal region (i.e., around the temples on the side of the skull). [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Large clumps of pigment irregularly distributed along hair shaft

Def: Reduced or lacking hair growth in a generalized distribution. [HPO:probinson]
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the sacral region. [HPO:probinson]
Anterior cervical hypertrichosis (ACH) or 'hairy throat' refers to the presence of a tuft of terminal hair on the anterior neck, just above the laryngeal prominence. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20400390]
A confluent, generalized overgrowth of silvery blonde to gray lanugo hair at birth. [HPO:probinson]
Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness. [HPO:probinson]
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates affecting the cervical spine. [HPO:probinson]
Increased bone density affecting the bones of the spine (vertebral column). [HPO:curators]

Bulbous appearance of the anterior vertebral bodies, such that the vertebral bodies have the greatest vertical height anteriorly as well as bulbous anterior superior-inferior contours. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16167086]
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T11 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front). [HPO:probinson]
Sclerosis (increased density) affecting vertebral end plates. [HPO:curators]
An excessive concavity of the anterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies. [HPO:curators]
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the thoracic spine. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Hump-shaped mound of bone in central and posterior portions of vertebral endplate

Def: Three ossification sites are present in typical vertebral bodies (C3-L5): a single ossification center in the vertebral body, and one each in the two neural arches. This term applies if there are additional vertebral ossification centers present during the development and maturation of the spine. [HPO:probinson]
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of the vertebra L5 with intact overlying skin. [HPO:probinson]

Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C2 and C3, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development, leading to a short neck with a low hairline at the back of the head, and restricted mobility of the upper spine. [HPO:probinson]
A lack of bone mineralization of the vertebral bodies. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Anterior beaking of lower thoracic vertebrae
Def: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the lower thoracic vertebral bodies. [HPO:probinson]
Anterior mislocalization of the dens of the axis. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal. [HPO:probinson, PMID:3160275]
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of S1 with intact overlying skin. [HPO:probinson]
A discontinuity of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra. [HPO:probinson]
Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends. [HPO:probinson]
Increased size of the vertebral pedicle. [HPO:probinson]
A progressive form of decreased height of the intervertebral disk. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of abnormal convexity of the upper and lower end plates of the vertebrae, i.e., an exaggerated bulging out of the upper and lower vertebral end plates. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced size of cervical vertebrae. [HPO:probinson]
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of thoracic vertebral bodies. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased cervical spine flexion due to contractures of posterior cervical muscles

Def: An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of cervical vertebrae during development. [HPO:probinson]
Over curvature of the lower thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump. [HPO:probinson]
Fusion of the C5 and C6 cervical vertebrae. [HPO:probinson]
An elevation of alpha-feto protein measured in the amniotic fluid. [HPO:curators]
Underdevelopment of the nasal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve). [HPO:probinson]
Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead). [HPO:curators]
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the midline region of the face. [HPO:curators]
Narrow, paramedian longitudinal depressions in the plantar skin of the forefoot. [PMID:19125433]
Outward turning of the heel, resulting in clubfoot with the person walking on the inner part of the foot. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the Third metatarsal bone leading to a short (hypoplastic) third metatarsal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Short fourth metatarsal bone. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal thickening of the Achilles tendon. [HPO:probinson]
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two and three. [HPO:sdoelken]
Syndactyly with fusion of toes four and five. [HPO:sdoelken]
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the calcaneus. [HPO:probinson]
Decrease in mass and density of the metatarsal bones. [HPO:probinson]
Short (hypoplastic) fifth metatarsal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Acute renal failure with resolution of manifestations. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal axial orientation of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
An increase in amplitude of waves returned in ultrasonography of the kidney, which is generally displayed as increased brightness of the signal. [HPO:probinson, PMID:2259758, PMID:24235286]
A defect in the ability to concentrate the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Acute inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the ability of the kidneys to remove uric acid from the serum. [HPO:probinson]
Cysts of microscopic size confined to the cortex of the kidney. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
Chronic inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules. [HPO:probinson]
Electron dense deposits at the glomerular basement membrane, [Eurenomics:ewuehl, PMID:20301598, PMID:30085237]
Episodes of ventricular tachycardia that have a sudden onset and ending. []
A form of atrioventricular (AV) dissociation (i.e., the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers) with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]

Atrial fibrillation (AF) that cannot be successfully terminated by cardioversion, and longstanding (more than 1 year) AF, where cardioversion is not indicated or has not been attempted, is termed permanent. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12860883]
Episodes of atrial fibrillation that typically last for several hours up to one day and terminate spontaneously. [HPO:probinson, PMID:30571060]
Polymorphic ventricular arrhythmias of varying morphologythat do not exist under resting conditions but appear only upon physical exercise or catecholamine administration. [PMID:15913575]
Underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart right ventricle, often due to a reduced number of cells. [MP:0010422]

The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands. Juvenile polyps are a specific type of hamartomatous polyps. [HPO:probinson, PMID:25022750]
An anatomical anomaly that results from an abnormal rotation of the gut as it returns to the abdominal cavity during embryogenesis. [HPO:probinson]
Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18825677]
Fluid retention and edema in the intestine caused by a compromised lymphatic system. [HPO:probinson]
An inability to digest lactose. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the small intestine. [HPO:probinson]
Defect in the epithelium of the esophagus, essentially an open sore in the lining of the esophagus. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a fistula between the perineum and the rectum. [HPO:probinson]
A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel. [HPO:probinson]
Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas located in the stomach. [HPO:probinson]

A form of hemolytic anemia that occurs in repeated episodes. [HPO:probinson]

A type of hypoplastic anemia with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]

A kind of hemolytic anemia that is induced by the ingestion of fava beans. [HPO:probinson]

An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors. [NCIT:C7463]
An excessive division of the lobes of the nucleus of a neutrophil. [HPO:probinson]
A type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence in the blood of erythrocytes of varying sizes and abnormal shapes. [HPO:probinson]

A type of acute myeloid leukemia in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate. [HPO:probinson]
A form of severe hemolytic anemia characterized by erythrocyte morphology reminiscent of that seen in patients after a thermal burn. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16304353]

Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade. [HPO:probinson]
A type of hemolytic anemia in which the Coombs test is positive. [HPO:probinson]

A subset of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that results from a reciprocal translocation between the ABL-1 oncogene and a breakpoint cluster region (BCR), resulting in a fusion gene, BCR-ABL, that encodes an oncogenic protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity. [PMID:21472706]
Repeated episodes of the formation of a blot clot in a deep vein. [HPO:probinson]
A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of folate. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced platelet count that occurs sporadically, i.e., it comes and goes. [HPO:probinson, PMID:8384898]
An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein S. Protein S is a cofactor of protein C. [HPO:probinson]
A type of anemia characterized by an normal concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes. [HPO:probinson]
A type of anemia characterized by abnormally large erythrocytes with abnormally high amounts of haemoglobin. [HPO:probinson]
Thrombocytopenia related to lack of or severe reduction in the count of megakaryocytes. [HPO:probinson]
A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of thiamine. [HPO:probinson]

The term Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) was initially used for patients diagnosed with fasting hyperglycemia that could be treated without insulin for more than two years, where the initial diagnosis was made at a young age (under 25 years). Thus, MODY combines characteristics of type 1 diabetes (young age at diagnosis) and type 2 diabetes (less insulin dependence than type 1 diabetes). The term MODY is now most often used to refer to a group of monogenic diseases with these characteristics. Here, the term is used to describe hyperglycemia diagnosed at a young age with no or minor insulin dependency, no evidence of insulin resistence, and lack of evidence of autoimmune destruction of the beta cells. [HPO:probinson]
A reduced concentration of vitamin A. []
Repeated transient episodes of metabolic acidosis, that is, of the buildup of acid or depletion of base due to accumulation of metabolic acids. [HPO:probinson]
An intermittent (discontinuous) form of lactic acidemia. [HPO:probinson]
Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood occurring during the infantile period. [HPO:probinson]
A form of metabolic acidosis with increased serum chloride levels. [PMID:31418093]
An increased concentration of L-phenylalanine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal resistance to glucose, i.e., a reduction in the ability to maintain glucose levels in the blood stream within normal limits following oral administration of glucose. [HPO:probinson]
A chronic form of lactic acidemia. [HPO:probinson]

Atherosclerosis which occurs in a person with certain risk factors (e.g., SLE, diabetes, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, family history of early heart disease) at an earlier age than would occur in another person without those risk factors. [PMID:29040156]
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the extracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall. [HPO:probinson]
A rare vascular anomaly with a direct communication between pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary bed. [PMID:27122941]
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries affecting most or all arteries. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17192541]

An abnormal increase in the average blood pressure in an individual during a single cardiac cycle. [PMID:18451345]

The dividing wall between left and right sides of the heart, thickens and bulges into the left ventricle. [http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/More/Cardiomyopathy/Hypertrophic-Cardiomyopathy_UCM_444317_Article.jsp#.WmePRJM-dL4, PMID:21349577]

The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation. [HPO:probinson, PMID:13316552]

A collection of pus in the area of the rectum. [HPO:probinson]

Obstruction affecting the biliary tree. [HPO:probinson]
A chronic form of gastritis. [HPO:probinson]

Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin. [HPO:probinson]

Tracheal cartilaginous sleeve (TCS) is a rare congenital airway malformation in which distinct tracheal rings are replaced by a continuous cartilaginous segment. Vertically fused C- or O-shaped cartilaginous rings can extend from the subglottis to the carina or bronchus with little to no pars membranacea posteriorly.\nComment:Tracheal cartilaginous sleeve has been associated with various craniosynostosis syndromes. [PMID:25375853]
Hypoplasia of the epiglottis. [HPO:probinson]
A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms. [PMID:18755723]
Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity. []
A reduced level of the complement component Factor I in circulation. [https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/135478-overview]

Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity. [GO:0030183]
Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to chicken pox, as manifested by recurrent episodes of chicken pox. []

Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to coronavirus 229e, as manifested by recurrent episodes of coronavirus 229e. []
An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
Def: A decreased proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormally increased level of circulating alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant. [PMID:15663032]
A reduced level of the complement component factor B in circulation. [https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/135478-overview]
Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific. [ISBN:0781735149]
A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation. [https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/135478-overview]
Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells []
An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway. []
Absence of specific immunoglobulins directed against a specific antigen or microorganism. [PMID:17100769]
An increased susceptibility to infections involving both the paranasal sinuses and the lungs, as manifested by a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections. [HPO:probinson]
Increased susceptibility to systemic pyogenic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of systemic pyogenic infections. [ORCID:0000-0001-7941-2961]

At birth, newborns are endowed with maternal antibodies. IgG production normally begins at the age of two months. A delay in recovery from this physiological hypogammaglobulinemia between the 3rd and the 6th month of life, and of recovery period between 18 and 36 months defines transient newborn hypogammaglobulinemia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
Def: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood. [HPO:probinson]
Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex. [HPO:probinson]
An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration. [HPO:curators]
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed. [HPO:curators]

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal. [HPO:probinson]
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull). [HPO:curators]
Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the frontal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull). [PMID:19125436]
Bony fusion of malleus, incus, and stapes. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed. [HPO:curators]
Progressively increasing bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour. [HPO:probinson]
A fontanelle that is small for age. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12825844]
Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125436]
The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
Def: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11711818]

Phenotype: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles

Def: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate. [HPO:probinson]

Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin M protein in the serum. [HPO:probinson, PMID:25815903]
A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation. [HPO:probinson]
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the ability of neutrophils to kill the gram-positive bacteria, staphylococcus, which is commonly known as staph. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staphylococcus_aureus]
Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow. [HPO:probinson]
A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas. [HPO:probinson]
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes. [HPO:probinson]

A chronic form of disseminated intravascular coagulation in which a persistent weak or intermittent activating stimulus is present and destruction and production of coagulation factors and platelets are balanced. [HPO:probinson]
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment. [HPO:probinson]
Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade. [DDD:wouwehand, HPO:probinson]
A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat. [DDD:wouwehand, HPO:probinson]

A type of actue leukemia with features characteristic of both the myeloid and lymphoid lineages. These leukemias are for this reason are designated mixed-lineage, hybrid or biphenotypic acute leukemias. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9107085]

A unique clonal neoplastic disorder that is linked to trisomy 21, is restricted to neonatal period, and spontaneously regresses. It often has characteristics of megakaryocytic lineage and is associated with GATA1 mutations in myeloblasts. [PMID:22966823]
A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion. [HPO:probinson]
Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval. [DDD:wouwehand]

A form of lymphoid leukemia or lymphoma in which too many T-cell lymphoblasts are found in the blood, bone marrow, and tissues. Leukemia or lymphoma classification depends on which feature is more prominent. [ISBN:9780721600406]
A form of poikilocytosis in which the abnormally shaped erythrocytes have notches that results in projections that look like horns. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va. [HPO:probinson]
A reduced count of megakaryocytes. [HPO:probinson]

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias. [HPO:curators]
The presence of many cysts in the kidney. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging. [HPO:probinson]
High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]

A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption without bicarbonate loss. [HPO:probinson]

A thrombotic microangiopathy with presence of non-immune, intravascular hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and acute kidney injury. A vicious cycle of complement activation, endothelial cell damage, platelet activation, and thrombosis is the hallmark of the disease. [PMID:19846853, PMID:28416508]

A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19144691, PMID:22449945]

Phenotype: Impaired renal ltubular reabsorption of chloride
Def: Any impairment of reabsorption of chloride by the kidney in order to not lose too much chloride in the urine. [PMID:25820368]
A duplication of the renal pelvis. [HPO:probinson]
DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in which only certain areas of the palms and soles are affected. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches

Def: Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution
Def: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution. [HPO:curators]

The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21139903]

Phenotype: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
Def: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium. [HPO:probinson, PMID:14571173, PMID:16553121, PMID:21170223]

An anomalous trapezoidal appearance of a vertebral body. A trapezoid is a four-sided shape that has two sides that are parallel and two sides that are not parallel. In this case, the two lateral sides of the vertebra are parallel, and the top and the bottom are slanted with respect to each other such that the vertebra is shorter in the fron or back than on the other side. [PMID:33247084]
Absent ossification of the calvaria (vault of the skull). [HPO:probinson]
Osteoporosis affecting predominantly the vertebrae. [HPO:curators]
Bony fusion of the posterior part of the L5 vertebral body with the sacrum. [PMID:5443339]
This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased anterioposterior diameter of lumbar vertebral bodies

Def: Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the third toe. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition of the intervertebral disk. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides. [HPO:probinson]
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints. [HPO:probinson]
Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity. [HPO:probinson]
Moderate osteoporosis. [HPO:curators]
Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes. [HPO:probinson]
Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella. [PMID:26668420]
Extreme thickening of the cortex of long bones. [HPO:curators]
Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. [HPO:probinson]
A tongue-like protusion from the anterior aspect of lumbar vertebral bodies. [PMID:25349664]

Phenotype: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole

Def: Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles. [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6548-5200]

Phenotype: Partial fusion of proximal row of carpal bones

Def: Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased bone density with cystic changes

Def: A bilateral form of triphalangeal thumb. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal reduction in length of all metacarpal bones. [HPO:probinson]
The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion. [HPO:curators]
A form of triphalangeal thumb that cannot be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance
Def: An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal related to a reduction in the interpedicular distance (i.e., the distance measured between the pedicles on frontal [coronal] imaging). [HPO:probinson]
Partial dislocation of the head of the radius in the posterior direction. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis
Def: Avascular necrosis of the proximal epiphysis of the femur occurring in growing children and caused by an interruption of the blood supply to the head of the femur close to the hip joint. The necrosis is characteristically associated with flattening of the femoral head, for which reason the term coxa plana has been used to refer to this feature in the medical literature. [HPO:probinson, PMID:29481348, PMID:30020602]

Phenotype: Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull
Def: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull). [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses during the neonatal period. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10084535]
An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa. [HPO:curators]
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the toes 2, 3, and 4. [HPO:probinson]
Bending or curvature of the distal phalanx of little finger in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger). [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of both forearm bones, the ulna and the radius, resulting in a shortened forearm. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Absent fourth finger distal interphalangeal crease
Def: Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fourth finger. [HPO:probinson]
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increase of bone mineral density with generalized involvement of the skeleton. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Cortical thickening of long bone diaphyses
Def: Abnormal thickening of the cortex of the diaphyseal region of long bones. [HPO:curators]
Underdevelopment of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the toes
Def: Abnormally short distal phalanx of toe of all toes. [HPO:probinson]
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an posterior direction. [HPO:probinson]
Aplasia (absence) of the distal phalanges. [HPO:curators]
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the foot on the lateral side (i.e., on the side of the little toe). [HPO:probinson]
Bending or curvature of a second toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe). [HPO:probinson]
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton

Def: An abnormally round shape of the middle phalanx of the finger. [HPO:probinson]
Generalized deposition of calcium salts within the brain. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before. [HPO:curators]
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an ulnar direction. [HPO:probinson]
In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals. [HPO:probinson]
A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae. [HPO:probinson, PMID:335375]
Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot. [HPO:probinson]
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe. [HPO:probinson]
Progressively worsening joint contractures. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Enlarged sagittal diameter of the cervical canal

Def: Multiple bent (flexed) finger joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Absent ossification of cervical vertebral bodies
Def: A lack of bone mineralization of one or more body of cervical vertebra. [HPO:probinson]
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the calvaria and the base of skull. [HPO:probinson]
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the forearm skeleton. [HPO:probinson]
Duplication of the metacarpal I bones. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Radial deviation of thumb terminal phalanx

Def: Severe degree of osteoporosis. [HPO:curators]
Presence of an angular or V -shaped indentation on the ulnar side of the fifth metacarpal bone (i.e., on the sides towards the fifth finger). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
Def: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Rhomboid or triangular shaped 5th finger middle phalanx
Def: Rhomboid or triangular shaped 5th (little) finger middle phalanx. [HPO:curators]

Diffuse filling of the distal airsspaces of the lungs, the alveoli, with macrophages. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present. [LMU:crapp, PMID:14338290, PMID:16728712, PMID:16738196, PMID:23728865, PMID:25657025]
Bilateral lack of development of the lungs. [HPO:probinson]
Blockage of the upper airway at the level of the larynx often accompanied by respiratory distress. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Ventilator dependence with inability to wean

Def: Reduced tendency to respond to a reduced concentration of oxygen in the blood by increasing respiration. [HPO:probinson]
Recurrent episodes of apnea occurring during infancy. [HPO:curators]
A membrane-like structure that extends across the laryngeal lumen close to the level of the vocal cords. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal shortening of the larynx in the anteroposterior (front to back) axis. [HPO:probinson]
An impairment of gluconeogenesis. [HPO:gcarletti]
A decreased concentration of arginine in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
Episodes of reduced body termperature. [HPO:probinson]
Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature. [HPO:curators]

Reduced intestinal absorption of fructose. Breath testing after ingestion of fructose has been widely adopted as a standard method of identifying fructose malabsorption and intolerance. A dose of 25 g of fructose dissolved in a 10% solution is generally accepted as the appropriate dose of fructose for clinical use of H2 and CH4 breath testing. High levels of hydrogen in exhaled breath subsequent hours indicate fructose intolerance. Presence of malabsorption and reproduction of symptoms during a breath test provides the best objective evidence and symptom correlation for fructose intolerance. [PMID:24357350]
Intermittent episodes of ketoacidosis. [HPO:probinson]
A metabolic acidosis due to accumulation of ketone bodies generally observed in the setting of poor nutritional intake. []
A reduction in phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase level. [HPO:probinson]
An elevation of alpha-feto protein in the maternal serum. [HPO:curators]
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. [DDD:spark]
A congenital form of torticollis resulting from shortening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and leading to a limited range of motion in both rotation and lateral bending. [HPO:probinson]
Excess skin around the neck, often lying in horizontal folds. [PMID:19125436]
Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced abilty to lower the chin towards the chest by bending the neck. []
Reduced amount of adipose tissue in the region of the neck. [HPO:probinson]
A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Hypotrophy of the small hand muscles

Def: Severely shortened metacarpal with a cuboidal appearance. [HPO:probinson]
Delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more phalanx. [HPO:probinson]
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the metacarpal bones. [HPO:curators]
Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones. [HPO:curators]
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones. [HPO:probinson]
A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers. [HPO:probinson]
Malalignement of carpal bone angles either with respect to each other, to the corresponding metacarpals or with respect to the wrist (radius and ulna). [HPO:sdoelken]
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four. [HPO:sdoelken]
Increased mobility of one ore more metacarpophalangeal joint. [HPO:probinson]
Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers. [HPO:curators]
Metacarpal that becomes thinner toward the distal end. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the fingers
Def: Short, hypoplastic middle phalanx of finger, affecting all fingers. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Expanded phalanges with widened medullary cavities

Def: The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the fingers
Def: Hypoplasia of all of the distal phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
A type of digital ulcer that manifests as an open sore on the surface of the skin at the tip of a finger or toe. [PMID:20862203]
Increased length of the proximal phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Rounding and broadening of the tufts of the distal phalanges. [HPO:probinson]
Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all proximal phalanges of the fingers
Def: Congenital hypoplasia of proximal phalanx of finger or all fingers. [HPO:probinson]

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal. [HPO:curators]
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
Def: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke. [HPO:curators]
Bending or curvature of a thumb towards the ulnar side (towards the ring finger). [HPO:probinson, PMID:10955488]
Irregular morphology of one or more metacarpal bones. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Short metacarpals with rounded proximal ends
Soft tissue swelling of interphalangeal joints

Def: A morphological abnormality of distal phalanges such that they have the appearance of chess pawns. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones

Def: Increase in bone density in the diaphyseal (shaft) region of a metacarpal bone. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth

Def: Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases. [PMID:19125433]
Excessively deep creases of the palm. [PMID:19125433]
Phalanges of the fingers becoming thinner toward the distal end. [HPO:probinson]

The middle phalanx of finger resembles a thimble, a small metal cap to protect the finger while sewing that has a broad (proximal) base and narrower top, whereby both base and top are flat. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased movement range in interphalangeal joints

Def: Alteration of the normally smooth radiographic contour of phalanges producing an irregular appearance. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of second finger
Def: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the second finger. [HPO:probinson]
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the proximal phalanges. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Thin proximal phalanges with broad epiphyses of the hand
Single interphalangeal crease of fifth finger
Def: Presence of only one (instead of two, as normal) interphalangeal crease of the fifth finger. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Limited mobility of proximal interphalangeal joint
Tapering pointed ends of distal finger phalanges
Def: A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end such that the tip of the phalanx comes to a point (this feature can be observed on radiograms). [HPO:probinson, PMID:10662807]

Phenotype: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities
Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint

Def: An increased resorption of bone matrix by osteoclasts leading to bony defects involving the tarsal bones. [HPO:sdoelken]
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the toes
Def: Abnormal shortening of all middle phalanges of toes. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced size of the placenta. [HPO:probinson]
Intermittently increased size of the spleen. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the spleen. [HPO:curators]
The presence of lymphangiectasis in the pancreas. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced number of beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans. [HPO:probinson]
Hyperplasia of the pancreas. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of pancreatic tissue outside the normal pancreas, in many cases along the foregut and proximal midgut. [HPO:curators]
A chronic form of pancreatitis. [HPO:probinson]
A generalized form of developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
The presence of multiple embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
The presence of discolored lateral incisors. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]

Phenotype: Marked delay in eruption of permanent teeth

Def: Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention. [HPO:probinson, WWW:wouwehand]
Dagger-shaped calcifications in the dental pulp. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A generalized form of microdontia. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A single maxillary central incisor positioned in the midline with morphological symmetry of the crown and bordered by lateral incisors. [PMID:19125428]
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Loss of the primary (also known as deciduous) teeth before the usual age. [HPO:sdoelken]
Underdevelopment of the alveolar process (also known as alveolar bone). [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, maxillary incisor, either the primary maxillary incisor or the permanent maxillary incisor. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A type of dental misalignment with crowded central incisors, i.e., of maxillary secondary incisor, or of maxillary central primary incisor. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Developmental hypoplasia of the primary teeth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Persistence of the primary teeth beyond the age by which they normally are shed and replaced by the permanent teeth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Tooth root length more than 2 SD below mean, or subjectively apparently decreased tooth root length. [HPO:probinson, PMID:31468724]
Premature tooth eruption of the permanent dentition. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
An abnormality of the morphology of secondary premolar tooth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary or permanent mandibular incisors. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A tooth crown with its mesial and distal sides converging or tapering toward the incisal edge causing severe reduction of mesiodistal diameter [HPO:ibailleulforestier, PMID:31468724]
An abnormality of morphology of primary molar. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
An abnormality of morphology of the incisor tooth in which the tooth is shaped like a screwdriver blade, i.e., having a rhomboid shape. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Decreased size of the primary teeth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A congenital defect characterized by the absence of one or more permanent teeth, including oligodontia, hypodontia, and adontia of the of permanent teeth. [HPO:probinson]
Mineralized substance filling the entire dental pulp space. [PMID:162890, PMID:31468724]

Phenotype: Failure of eruption of permanent teeth
Def: Lack of tooth eruption of the secondary dentition. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Developmental hypoplasia of the tooth germ, i.e., of the structure that forms in odontogenesis that will develop into a tooth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
Premature loss of the permanent teeth. [HPO:ibailleulforestier]
A tooth with a crown with marked lingual or palatal marginal ridges causing scooped lingual or palatal surfaces. [PMID:2212205, PMID:31468724]

An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta. [HPO:probinson]
An alteration of the normally relatively smooth margins of the kneecap in radiographic images leading to an irregular contour. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the distal epiphysis of the ulna. [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the diaphysis of long bones. [HPO:probinson]
The femur is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses. [HPO:probinson]
A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. [HPO:probinson]
Absent or nearly absent fibula. (Does not include aplastic) []
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the distal end. This feature affects the distal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis. [HPO:probinson]
Shortening of the legs related to developmental hypoplasia of the bones of the leg. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the distal epiphysis of the radius. [HPO:curators]
Increased width of the distal part of the shaft (metaphysis) of the femur. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability to flex (bend) the knee joint. []
An abnormal anterior bending or curvature of the tibia. [HPO:probinson]
Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones. [HPO:probinson]

A limitation of the ability to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces anteriorly (supination) and to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces posteriorly (pronation). [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal flattening of the distal epiphysis of femur. [HPO:sdoelken]
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the proximal end. This feature affects the proximal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis. [HPO:probinson]
Anomaly of the contour of the Distal epiphysis of femur such that its normally smooth appearance is irregular. [HPO:probinson]
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the leg. [HPO:probinson]
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the tibia. [HPO:probinson]
Increased density of the compact bone of long bone. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of asymmetric developmental dysplasia of the radius. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses

Def: Increased length of the radius. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally wide femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft). [HPO:probinson]
Proximal radial shortening owing to a congenital defect of development. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Disproportionate prominence of the femoral medial condyle
Enlargement of the distal femoral epiphysis
Def: An abnormal enlargement of the distal epiphysis of the femur. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased density of long bone diaphyses

Def: Underdevelopment or shortening of the end of the fibula (calf bone) nearest the knee. [PMID:880750]
Absence of the patella. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Multicentric ossification of proximal femoral epiphyses
Lateral displacement of the femoral head
Def: A developmental anomaly with lateral displacement of the femoral head. [HPO:probinson]
Formation of bone in the patella later than normal. [HPO:probinson, PMID:6729496]
Anomaly of the contour of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia such that its normally smooth appearance is irregular. [HPO:probinson]
Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction. [HPO:curators]

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is defined as a posterior and inferior slippage of the proximal epiphysis of the femur onto the metaphysis (femoral neck), occurring through the physeal plate during the early adolescent growth spurt. [HPO:probinson]
A generalized decrease in bone mineral density. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
Def: Thickening of the periosteum of long bone. [HPO:probinson]
A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased width of the diaphysis of long bones. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal anterior curvature of a long bone. [HPO:probinson]

Tracheal diverticula are blind-ended outpouchings arising from the trachea. They are usually an incidental finding. Occasionally they can mimic pneumomediastinum. Tracheal diverticula are either congenital or acquired, in the latter case the most common causes are prolonged increased intraluminal pressure, e.g. chronic cough, COPD, tracheomalacia, and iatrogenic (e.g. post-surgical). [PMID:18544671, PMID:27867581]
An anomaly that is characterized progressive airflow obstruction that is only partly reversible, inflammation in the airways, and systemic effects or comorbities. [PMID:25943942]
An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat. [HPO:probinson]

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis involves inhalation of an antigen. This leads to an exaggerated immune response and a following inflammation of the alveoli within the lungs. The main feature of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis on lung biopsies is expansion of the interstitium by lymphocytes accompanied by an occasional multinucleated giant cell or loose granuloma. After exposure to the provoking antigen, following symptoms can be seen: fever, chills, malaise, cough, hemoptysis, chest tightness, dyspnea, rash, swelling and headache and can be completely reversible, based on the duration of the illness, categorized as acute (HP:0011009), subacute (HP:0011011), and chronic (HP:0011010). [LMU:mgriese, PMID:15316440, PMID:16635083, PMID:18051218]

Accumulation of amorphous PAS-positive material in the space betweem alveolar macrophages, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21900000, PMID:22891182]

Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition. [HPO:probinson, NIHR:ldaugherty, PMID:20456932, PMID:27009171]
Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus. [HPO:probinson]

Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid. [HPO:probinson]

Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis is a benign lymphoproliferative disorder of the lung that is characterized by the presence of a dense, predominantly lymphocytic interstitial infiltrate (lymphocytes, plasma cells, other elements of the lymphoreticular system) that expands the alveolar septa. [HPO:probinson, PMID:32040879]

According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities. [IMM:tkuijpers]
A recurrent hemorrhage occurring within the lung. [HPO:gcarletti]
An increased susceptibility to bronchopulmonary infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchopulmonary infections. [HPO:probinson]

A type of pulmonary sequestration that is completely enclosed in its own pleural sac, occurring above, within, or below the diaphragm, and without communication with the tracheobronchial tree. [HPO:probinson]

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins. [PMID:30386957, PMID:788535]
A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
Def: Decreased activity of complex III of the mitochondrion in the liver. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver. [HPO:probinson]
Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

Def: Intermittently increased size of the liver. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes. [HPO:probinson]
An increase in the amount of glycogen stored in hepatocytes compared to normal. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
Def: The presence of reduced numbers of intrahepatic bile duct than normal. [HPO:probinson]
An acute form of hepatic steatosis. [HPO:probinson]
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules. [HPO:probinson]

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants. [HPO:probinson]
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
Def: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes. [HPO:probinson]
Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure. []

The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically.
