Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22295044]
An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved . [HPO:probinson]
Prematurely closed sternal sutures. [HPO:probinson, PMID:13542801]
Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]
Bony fusion between the humerus and scapula, leading to an impairment in mobility of the affected shoulder joint. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm. [HPO:probinson, PMID:3612666]

Phenotype: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends

Def: Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth border between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum. [HPO:probinson]
Early ossification of the costochondral junction, which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10489169]
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle. [HPO:probinson]
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
Def: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10204210]
Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero. [HPO:probinson]
Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal increase in density of the tissue at the costochondral junctions. [HPO:probinson]
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal. [HPO:probinson]
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus. [HPO:probinson]
Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass). [HPO:probinson]
Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle. [HPO:probinson]
More than one fracture of the ribs. [HPO:probinson]

Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax. [HPO:probinson]
Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Thickening of the lateral border of the scapula

Def: Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger). [HPO:probinson, PMID:12712270, PMID:21607596]
Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec. [HPO:probinson]

Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells. [HPO:probinson, PMID:937513]
An abnormality of filling of a ventricle with blood during diastole. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways
Def: A form of ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of multiple accessory pathways for cardiac conduction. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium. [HPO:probinson, PMID:29043203]
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta. [HPO:probinson]
A bacterial infection of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves. [HPO:sdoelken]
Calcium deposition in the myocardium. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
Def: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve. [HPO:probinson]
Steatosis in the myocardium. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Early progressive calcific cardiac valvular disease

Def: A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites. []
Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20448134]
The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. [HPO:probinson]
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia of T-cell origin. It comprises about 15% of childhood cases and 25% of adult cases. It is more common in males than females. [NCIT:C3183]
The presence of an follicular adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]

A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma in which the papillae are covered by large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and nuclear pseudostratification. [DDD:rscott, PMID:12429790]
A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts. []
The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Def: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
Def: The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder with origin in a transitional epithelial cell. [HPO:probinson]
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone. [HPO:probinson]
Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla. [HPO:curators]
The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis. [HPO:probinson]
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells. [HPO:probinson]
A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron. [DDD:rscott]
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary. [HPO:probinson]
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton. [HPO:sdoelken]
A non-malignant neoplasm of the genitourinary system. [HPO:probinson]
A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism. [HPO:probinson]
A kind of thyroid adenoma characterized by the presence of oxyphil cells. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses. [HPO:probinson]
Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders). [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Loss of ability to walk in first decade

Def: Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the white matter of the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region

Def: A form of lissencephaly in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development. At neuropathological examination, a 4-layered cortex consists of an upper molecular layer, a second thin cellular layer containing pyramidal neurons usually observed in layer V, a third pale poorly cellular layer and a fourth thick deep layer made up of neurons which had failed to migrate. Radiologocally would manifest as agyria or pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm. [COST:neuromig, HPO:probinson, PMID:28440899]

A type of polymicrogyria with a gradient of severity (anterior more severe than posterior) extending from frontal poles posteriorly to precentral gyrus and inferiorly to frontal operculum. [COST:neuromig, PMID:20301504]

Phenotype: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord
Def: An abnormally pale appearance of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. This finding can be observed by histological examination. []
A severe degree of muscular hypotonia characterized by markedly reduced muscle tone. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
Def: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy. [HPO:probinson]
A type of Horner syndrome with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella. [HPO:probinson]
Developmental defect characterized by a small and malformed corpus callosum. []
Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the pons. [HPO:probinson]
Multiple neurofibromas of the spinal nerve roots with a symmetric distribution. [HPO:probinson]
The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia. [HPO:curators]
Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints. [HPO:probinson]
A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts. [DDD:hvfirth]

Phenotype: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs

Def: A type of holoprosencephaly in which most of the right and left cerebral hemispheres and lateral ventricles are separated but the most rostral aspect of the telencephalon, the frontal lobes, are fused, especially ventrally. [gc:hpe]
A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]
A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum. [HPO:probinson]
A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time. [HPO:probinson]
Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-85. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20537050]
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the frontotemporal cerebrum. [HPO:probinson]
Fleeting perceptual experiences that occur during the transition from sleep to wakefulness. [PMID:27358492]

Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia. [PMID:29489275]
The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures that is present already at the time of birth. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the frontal cortex. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Intraaxonal accumulation of curvilinear autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
Def: Curvilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material within axons. [HPO:probinson]
Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature. [HPO:probinson]

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cortex of frontal lobe and the cortex of parietal lobe. [HPO:probinson]

A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus. [HPO:probinson]

A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles. [HPO:probinson]
A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration. [HPO:curators]
Hypoplasia of the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus. [HPO:probinson]
Proximal spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem. [HPO:curators]
The presence of calcium deposition in the choroid plexus. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Gait instability, worse in the dark

Def: Periventricular leukomalacia is characterized by diffuse injury of deep cerebral white matter, accompanied in its most severe form by focal necrosis. The neuropathologic hallmarks of PVL are microglial activation and focal and diffuse periventricular depletion of premyelinating oligodendroglia. [PMID:16808630, PMID:18852342, PMID:28406931]
A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue. [KI:phemming, PMID:23705127]
Leukoencephalopathy that gets more severe with time. [HPO:probinson]
A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged. [gc:hpe]

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21263138]
A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons. [HPO:probinson]
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the basal ganglia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellar vermis

Def: Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg. [HPO:probinson]
The formation of small cavities in the tissue of the basal ganglia. [HPO:probinson, PMID:8516046]

An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of small muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Fine motor skills are required to mediate movements of the wrists, hands, fingers, feet, and toes. []

Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]

An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of large muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Gross motor skills are required to mediate movements of the arms, legs, and other large body parts. []

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient. [HPO:curators]
Inability to perceive painful stimuli. [HPO:probinson]
Cerebral hemorrhage that occurs before birth. [HPO:probinson]

Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. Pseudobulbar paralysis is characterized clinically by dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia with bifacial paralysis, and may be accompanied by Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms such as enforced crying and laughing. [HPO:sdoelken]
A morphological abnormality of the metencephalon. [HPO:probinson]
A small, sac-like aneurysm (outpouching) of a cerebral blood vessel. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia

Def: Meningitis that persists for more than 4 weeks, and lymphocytes are present in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). [PMID:27608867]
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of dentate nucleus. [HPO:probinson]
Increased size of the basal ganglia. [HPO:probinson]
Generalized atrophy or hypoplasia of the cerebrum. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Aplasia of the inferior half of the cerebellar vermis

Def: Progressive loss of previously present language abilities. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Disorganization of the anterior cerebellar vermis

Def: Stiffness of the limbs (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in the proximal limb muscle. [https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5208-3432]
Peripheral sensory neuropathy affecting primarily distal sensation. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16580298]
Increased vertical dimension of the corpus callosum. This feature can be visualized by sagittal sections on magnetic resonance tomography imaging of the brain. [KI:phemming, PMID:10029348]
An increase in size of the third ventricle. [HPO:probinson]
Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements. [HPO:probinson]

Arnold-Chiari type I malformation refers to a relatively mild degree of herniation of the posteroinferior region of the cerebellum (the cerebellar tonsils) into the cervical canal with little or no displacement of the fourth ventricle. It is characterized by one or both pointed (not rounded) cerebellar tonsils that project 5 mm below the foramen magnum, measured by a line drawn from the basion to the opisthion (McRae Line) [HPO:curators, PMID:28613730]
Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period. [HPO:probinson]
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers from segments of the peripheral nervous system. [HPO:probinson]

A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change. [HPO:probinson, PMID:4819905]
Acute progressive areflexic weakness and mild sensory changes resulting from myelin breakdown and axonal degeneration. [HPO:probinson]
Neurodegeneration involving the globus pallidus,a part of the basal ganglia that is involved in the regulation of voluntary movement. [HPO:probinson]
Stiffness of the limbs (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in an asymmetric pattern. [HPO:probinson]
A progressive degree of muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Diffuse demyelination of the cerebral white matter
Def: A diffuse loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks. [HPO:probinson]
A complete lack of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex. [KI:phemming]
Facial diplegia (that is, bilateral facial palsy) with congenital onset. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex

Def: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure of either generalized or focal onset occurring on or soon after wakening (typically within 90 minutes of waking, regardless of the time of day). [HPO:probinson, PMID:24395517, PMID:26948972]
Atherosclerosis (HP:0002621) of a cerebral artery. [HPO:probinson]
Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17416820]
Generalized-onset tonic-clonic seizures that are provoked by flashing or flickering light. [HPO:probinson, PMID:28276060]
Presence of irregular redundant loops of focally folded myelin in a peripheral nerve. [PMID:20301641, PMID:8817346]
Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve). [HPO:probinson]
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with elevated levels of potassium in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Demyelination of peripheral motor nerves. [HPO:probinson]
Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of calcium deposition in the cerebral white matter surrounding the cerebral ventricles. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential
Def: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential in distal nerve segments. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Spinocerebellar tract disease in lower limbs

Def: Groups of small caliber axons in peripheral nerve biospies indicative of axonal regeneration. [HPO:jbaets]
A type of gait ataxia displaying progression of clinical severity. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers

Def: Alternating and recurrent weakness of the external ocular muscles. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Severe demyelination of the white matter
Def: A severe loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson]
A form of lissencephaly characterized by an uneven cortical surface with a so called 'cobblestone' appearace. There are no distinguishable cortical layers. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord. [HPO:probinson]
Agenesis of the midbrain. [KI:phemming]
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths of the white matter of the brain. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality characterized by chronic impairment of the normal functioning of the axons. [HPO:probinson]

An atypical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by interruption of ongoing activities and reduced responsiveness. In comparison to a typical absence seizure, changes in tone may be more pronounced, onset and/or cessation may be less abrupt, and the duration of the ictus and post-ictal recovery may be longer. Although not always available, an EEG often demonstrates slow (<3 Hz), irregular, generalized spike-wave activity. [HPO:probinson, PMID:28276060, PMID:28276062, PMID:28276064, PMID:6790275]
An increased susceptibility to bacterial meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of bacterial meningitis. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons
Facial palsy secondary to cranial hyperostosis
Def: Paralysis of the facial nerves on the basis of overgrowth of the cranial bones causing impingement upon the seventh cranial nerve. [HPO:probinson]
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements, in which the movement in one direction is faster than in the other. [HPO:probinson]
Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs. [HPO:curators]

Oral-motor apraxia is the inability to volitionally sequence oral movements of the speech structure for nonspeech tasks in the absence of neuromuscular deficits such as paralysis or muscle weakness. Oral-motor apraxia is diagnosed when, despite intact sensory motor function an individual is unable to use these effector systems under voluntary control. [PMID:26275812]
Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the deep cerebral white matter. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16239634]
A type of dystonia that affects all or most of the body. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the frontal lobe of the cerebrum. [HPO:sdoelken]
Recurrent episodes of brain dysfunction that may be triggered by factors such as metabolic disturbances or infections. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter

Def: A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the corpus callosum. [HPO:sdoelken]
A type of ichthyosiform erythroderma with postnatal onset. [HPO:probinson]
Photosensitivity of the skin occurring early in life. [HPO:probinson]
Developmental hypoplasia of the apocrine sweat glands in the region of the axilla. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation that do not follow Blaschko lines

Def: Abnormal thickening of the skin on the palms and soles charactersized by hyperkeratosis of the stratum corneum with no evidence of epidermolysis characteristic of epidermolytic hyperkeratosis. [PMID:7528239]

Phenotype: Excessive skin wrinkling on dorsum of hands and fingers

Def: Increased susceptibility to infection by the protozan parasite of the genus Leishmania. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles. [HPO:probinson]
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the forehead. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Neonatal wrinkled skin of hands and feet

Def: Cutaneous lesion that develops as a dry, scaly, red patch that evolves to an indurated and hyperpigmented plaque with adherent scale. Scarring may result in central white patches (loss of pigmentation) and skin atrophy. []
Spontaneous development of hematomas (hematoma) or bruises without significant trauma. [DDD:akelly]
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the cheeks. [HPO:curators]
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the oral mucosa. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of two to five cafe-au-lait macules. [DDD:cmoss]
Hemangioma is a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells. This term refers to facial hemangiomas that have a plaque-like morphology. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of multiple leiomyomas of the skin. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Mottled pigmentation of the trunk and proximal extremities

Def: Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs. [HPO:probinson]
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. [HPO:probinson]
Diffuse abnormal thickening of the skin on the palms and soles. [PMID:17298101]

Phenotype: Increased groin pigmentation with raindrop depigmentation

Def: Inability to sweat on the same side of the face that is affected by ptosis and miosis. This is a feature of Horner syndrome. [PMID:29763176]
Lichenification affecting primarily flexural areas of the skin. [HPO:probinson]
Prominent thoracic and abdominal veins. [HPO:probinson]
Keratinization of the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus (corneoscleral junction), resulting in a raised spot. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced number or density of facial hair. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal thickening of the skin on the palms and soles with an honeycomb pattern. [PMID:9326323]
Increased amount of keratin (visible as white scales) surrounding hair follicles. [PMID:23044575]
Cutis gyrata of palms and soles. [HPO:probinson]
Subcutaneous nodules that are located in the vicinity of joints. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Axillary and groin hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation

Def: An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin that presents at birth or shortly thereafter with generalized erythema, blistering, erosions, and peeling. In the subsequent months, erythema and blistering improves but patients go on to develop hyperkeratotic scaling that is especially prominent along the joint flexures, neck, hands and feet. [HPO:probinson]

The term collodion baby applies to newborns who appear to have an extra layer of skin (known as a collodion membrane) that has a collodion-like quality. It is a descriptive term, not a specific diagnosis or disorder (as such, it is a syndrome). Affected babies are born in a collodion membrane, a shiny waxy outer layer to the skin. This is shed 10-14 days after birth, revealing the main symptom of the disease, extensive scaling of the skin caused by hyperkeratosis. With increasing age, the scaling tends to be concentrated around joints in areas such as the groin, the armpits, the inside of the elbow and the neck. The scales often tile the skin and may resemble fish scales. [HPO:sdoelken]

Phenotype: Decreased sweating due to autonomic dysfunction

Def: Lack of subcutaneous adipose tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) with a diffuse localization. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Linear arrays of macular hyperkeratoses in flexural areas
Discrete 2 to 5-mm hyper- and hypopigmented macules

Def: Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot in areas exposed to friction. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of fewer than normal sweat glands. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Streaks of hyperkeratosis along each finger onto the palm

Def: A skin condition characterized by excessive development of keratin in hair follicles, resulting in rough, cone-shaped, elevated papules resulting from closure of hair follicles with a white plug of sebum. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Congenital absence of skin of limbs

Def: Tiny bumps of thickened skin (hyperkeratosis) on the palms of the hands. []

Phenotype: Edema of the dorsum of hands
Def: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the hands. [HPO:probinson]
Loose and sagging skin of the fingers. [HPO:probinson]
Loose, wrinkled skin of hands and feet. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Yellow subcutaneous tissue covered by thin, scaly skin

Def: Loss of hair in the occipital region of the scalp with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Aplasia cutis congenita of midline scalp vertex

Def: A severe degree of photosensitivity of the skin. [HPO:curators]
Presence of a cutaneous lipoma on the forehead. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Absent pigmentation of the ventral chest
Def: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the anterior chest. [HPO:probinson]

Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal thickening of the skin on the palms and soles that is present at birth. []

Phenotype: Desquamation of skin soon after birth
Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin

Def: The presence of six or more cafe-au-lait spots. [DDD:cmoss]
Seborrheic dermatitis that is not localized to any one particular region. []

Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans (HLP), also known as Flegel disease, is a keratinization abnormality characterized by small, asymptomatic erythematous papules that leave characteristic punctate bleeding when they become detached. The lesions generally occur symmetrically along the top of the foot and on the legs, appearing more rarely on the arms, forearms, palms, and soles, and even on the oral mucosa. [HPO:probinson]
A form of atopic dermatitis with onset in adulthood characterized by atopic red face, chronic lichenified eczema on the trunk, subacute or psoriasiform dermatitis. [PMID:23984225, PMID:27904186]
Increased pigmentation of the skin with a netlike (reticular) pattern. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Aplasia cutis congenita on trunk or limbs
Def: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the trunk or the limbs. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Aplasia cutis congenita over posterior parietal area

Def: The presence of multiple subcutaneous lipoma that cause pain. [HPO:probinson]
The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body because of decreased osmotic pressure of plasma (hypoproteinemia). [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles

Def: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the neck. This is one of the most common birthmarks and present in approximately 25% of all newborns. [HPO:sdoelken]
Deposition of calcium salts in subcutaneous tissue (i.e., the the lowermost layer of the integument). [HPO:probinson]
The presence of leiomyoma of the skin. [HPO:probinson]
Osteomyelitis of the lower jaw. []
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes. [HPO:curators]

An acute condition characterized by sudden visual loss (usually discovered in the morning), optic disc edema at onset, optic disc-related visual field defects. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can be associated with flame hemorrhages on the swollen disc or nearby neuroretinal layer, and sometimes with nearby cotton-wool exudates. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17698200]
Tractional retinal detachment at the periphery of the retina. []
Lack of eyelashes on the lower lid. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital abnormality of the extraocular muscles. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids

Def: A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland. [HPO:probinson]
Opacity of the entire lens nucleus. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes. [HPO:curators]

Degenerative changes of the peripheral retina consisting of close-packed tiny cystic spaces at the outer plexiform/inner nuclear retinal level. The degeneration is very common in adult eyes and starts adjacent to the ora serrata and extends circumferentially and posteriorly. [ORCID:0000-0003-0986-4123]
Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula. [DDD:gblack, PMID:18289629]
Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct). [HPO:probinson]
A unilateral form of ptosis. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the lower eyelid. [HPO:probinson]
Sudden-onset episode of abnormal, involuntary eye movements. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of the crystalline lens of the eye as a result of a developmental defect. [HPO:probinson]
A type of genetically determined disease of the cornea with corneal lesions with a band-like shape. []
A chronic irritative conjunctivitis, which commonly presents with general irritation and redness of the eyes, with a burning, dry, or foreign-body sensation of the eyes. [HPO:curators]

Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of multiple dilatations (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal development of the choroid and retina. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally big lacrimal glands. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina
Def: Pigment migration into the retina in a bone-spicule configuration (resembling the nucleated cells within the lacuna of bone). [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the fovea centralis. [HPO:probinson]
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point. [HPO:probinson]
Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of retinal blood vessels (arteries, arterioles, veins, venules). [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the ciliary body. [HPO:probinson]
Fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound (i.e., a scar) located in the choroid and retina or the eye. []
A type of retinal neovascularization that affects the posterior pole of the retina. [HPO:probinson]
A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
Def: Wasting (atrophy) of the retinal pigment epithelium present in small, isolated areas. []
Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea. [HPO:probinson]
A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of whitish deposits in the conjunctiva resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased axial length of the globe
Def: Abnormal largeness of the eye with an axial length > 2.5 standard deviations from population mean. [DDD:ncarter]

The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material. [HPO:curators]
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity. [HPO:probinson]

The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining. [HPO:probinson]
A form of uveitis that is not associated with the formation of granulomas. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Abnormal distribution of retinal arterioles and venules

Def: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone. [HPO:probinson]
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17030721]
Congenital absence or closure of the opening of the lacrimal punctum. [HPO:probinson]
Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles. [HPO:probinson]
Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood. [HPO:probinson]

Nonprogressive restriction of movement of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited. [HPO:probinson]
A kind of cataract that progresses with age. [HPO:probinson]
A progressive form of ptosis. [HPO:probinson]
Increased length of the upper eyelashes. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humor
Def: Deposition of hyaline extracellular material (amyloid) into the vitreous humor, which can manifest as vitreous opacities and reduced visual acuity. [HPO:probinson]
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina. [HPO:probinson]
Horizontal nystagmus dating from or present at birth. [HPO:curators]
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina. [HPO:probinson]
Fibrosis of only some of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. [HPO:probinson]

The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas. [HPO:probinson]

A shape created by an acute downward arching of the upper eyelid and upward arching of the lower eyelid, toward the medial canthus, which gives the outline of the palpebral fissures the configuration of an almond. Thus, the maximum distance between the fissures is offset from, and medial to, the center point. [PMID:19125427]
Blindness with onset at birth. [HPO:probinson]
Allergic Conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles. [HPO:probinson]
A type of posterior subcapsular cataract characterized by an iridescent color. [HPO:probinson, PMID:7826272]
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal puncta. [HPO:probinson]
Failure of attachment of the retina during development. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21441919]
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye. [DDD:akelly, PMID:16882398]
Chorioretinal atrophy along the retinal veins. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15623792]
Intraocular pressure that is 2 standard deviations above the population mean. []
A type of of patterned retinal dystrophy that shows a reticular pattern of pigmentation. []

This corneal dystrophy affects the posterior limiting membrane of the cornea and is characterized by polymorphous plaques of calcium deposits in the deep stromal layers of the cornea, and occasionally by vesicular lesions of the endothelium and edema of the deep corneal stroma. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct. [HPO:probinson]
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium occuring near the outer limit (periphery) of the retina. []
Congenital abnormal dilation of the pupil on both sides. [HPO:probinson]
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow. [HPO:probinson]
A type of retinal reticular pigmentation that forms a polygonal, netlike arrangement of hyperpigmented lines forming geometric patterns in the fundus. [HPO:fprobst, PMID:28114409]
A form of monochromacy in which vision is derived from the remaining preserved blue (S) cones and rod photoreceptors. [HPO:probinson]
Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus. [HPO:probinson]
A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset. [HPO:probinson]
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures on one side only. [HPO:probinson]

A subtype of retinitis pigmentosa in which, instead of the pathology starting in the mid-periphery like typical retinitis pigmentosa, the disease starts in the near periphery closer to the vascular arcades and tends to spare the far periphery. [ORCID:0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:28981474]
A type of posterior cortical cataract characterized by dense lenticular opacities. [HPO:probinson]
Chorioretinal atrophy concentrated around the optic papilla (i.e., the optic nerve head). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression

Def: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina. [HPO:probinson]

Saccadic undershoot of horizontal saccadic eye movements, i.e., a horizontal saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object. [HPO:probinson, PMID:572501]

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19496508, PMID:9158139]
Horizontal nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left. [HPO:curators]

A dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram in which the b-wave that is of markedly lower amplitude than the associated a-wave (source: Holder GE., Inherited Chorioretinal Dystrophies: A Textbook and Atlas; 2014; p.17; ISBN 978-3-540-69466-3). [HPO:probinson]
Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea. [DDD:ncarter]
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment of the stroma of iris. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital malformation of the lacrimal duct associated with incomplete development of the bony nasolacrimal canal or craniofacial anomalies. [HPO:probinson]
Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids. [HPO:probinson]
Increased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis. [HPO:probinson]

Microscopic aneurysms of the retinal arterioles near the central part of the fundus, visible as small round dark red dots on the retinal surface (not arising from visible vessels) that are by definition less than the diameter of the major optic veins as they cross the optic disc. [HPO:probinson]
Partial dislocation of the lens in a superior direction. [HPO:probinson, PMID:5087595]
Inherited progressive cone degeneration. []
A form of macular degeneration characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the macula. [HPO:probinson]
A type of sutural cataract in which the opacity follows the posterior Y suture. [HPO:probinson]

Retinitis pigmentosa inversa is form of retinal degeneration characterized by areas of retinal/chorioretinal degeneration with pigment migration in the macular area (in contrast to retinitis pigmentosa which, at early disease stages, predominantly affects the retinal periphery). [ORCID:0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:9734800]

Phenotype: Absent anterior chamber of the eye
Def: Absence of the anterior chamber of the eye owing to a developmental defect. []
Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina. [HPO:probinson]
Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy. [HPO:sdoelken]

Virilization (deepening of voice, facial hirsutism and scalp hair loss) with onset during pregnancy (usually towards the end of the first trimester) and regression several months post-partum. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally low concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age. [PMID:19038077]
The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age. [HPO:probinson]
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones. [HPO:probinson]
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence of the fifth metatarsal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially. [HPO:curators]
An outward deviation of the foot at the talocalcaneal or subtalar joint. []
The presence of a fifth metatarsal bone that has not undergone ossification at an age when ossification is usually visible. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the fourth toe. [HPO:probinson]
An overall widening of the spaces between the digits. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125433]
Osteolysis affecting the talus. [HPO:sdoelken]
Medial deviation of the second toe. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Expanded metatarsals with widened medullary cavities
Plantar crease between first and second toes
Def: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot located between the first and second toe. [HPO:probinson]
Precocious (accelerated) maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones. [HPO:probinson]
Osteosclerosis of the endosteal surface of the diaphyses (shafts) of the metatarsal bones. [HPO:curators]
Bending or curvature of a third toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe). [HPO:probinson]
Limitation of the ability to bend the toes. [HPO:probinson]
Synostosis of the calcaneus with the navicular bone. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus. [HPO:probinson]
A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more tarsal bones. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Medial rotation of the medial malleolus

Def: Defective ossification in an irregular pattern of the seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones. [HPO:probinson]

Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees. [HPO:probinson]
Delayed maturation and calcification of the calcaneus. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal response to epinephrine as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of epinephrine. [DDD:wouwehand]
Elevations of the levels of SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) that occur during infections. [HPO:curators]

Increased time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT. [HPO:probinson, PMID:26351955, PMID:29939529]
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with reduced levels of potassium in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

Hyperapobetalipoproteinemia is defined as the combination of a normal low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the face of an increased LDL apolipoprotein B (apoB) protein. [HPO:probinson, PMID:6579550]
An increase in the level of 3-hydroxydicarboxylic acid in the urine. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Alkaline phosphatase levels measured within leukocytes is below detectable levels. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood not associated with symptoms such as encephalopathy. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally reduced concentration of cortisol in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced proportion of helper T cells relative to the total number of T cells. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally decreased rate of beta-galactosidase activity. Beta-galactosidase activity can be measured in leukocyte, fibroblast, or plasma. [HPO:gcarletti]

Def: Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal reduction in the Arden ratio, which is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record. [HPO:probinson]
An absence of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys. [HPO:curators]
The presence of large polyhedral cells with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei in the adrenal cortex. [HPO:probinson]
No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased sensitivity toward insulin. [HPO:probinson]
The congenital absence of the thyroid gland. [HPO:probinson, PMID:2918525]
The presence of multiple pancreatic islet cell adenomas. [HPO:probinsojn]

A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia. [HPO:probinson]

A reduced level of prolactin in the blood circulation. Prolactin is a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production. [DDD:spark, HPO:probinson, PMID:23378139]

Def: Ketosis-resistant diabetes is a synonym for type II diabetes. This term thus refers to a form of type II diabetes in which patients are dependent on insulin. [HPO:probinson]
Hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]

Amenorrhea due to loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. Primary ovarian inssuficiency (POI) is a state of female hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. It can manifest as primary amenorrhea with onset before menarche or secondary amenorrhea. [HPO:probinson]
Aplasia of the parathyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]

A reduced ability to secrete gonadotropins, which are protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary gland, including the hormones follitropin (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). [DDD:spark]

Condition associated with a raised serum concentration of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) but a normal serum free thyroxine (FT4). [PMID:28406057]

An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation. [HPO:probinson]

A progressive disorder of vertebral joint degeneration that occurs in the setting of any condition characterized by decreased afferent innervation, involving loss of deep pain and proprioceptive sensation in the vertebral column. Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. [PMID:23885280]
A developmental anomaly of the ureter. [HPO:probinson]

Congenital absence of the lumen of the larynx. Laryngeal atresia is a rare condition. If the laryngeal opening fails to develop, fluid secreted by the lungs cannot be expelled. In a fetus with laryngeal atresia, the lungs are either normal or hyperplastic, not hypoplastic. Mortality is reported as 100%. At obstetric US examination, views of the fetal neck demonstrate a dilated trachea filled with trapped fluid. Views of the fetal chest show enlarged, hyperechoic lungs, with dilated fluid-filled bronchi. Fetal ascites is usually present. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10517457, PMID:17715321]
Presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17178945]

Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the laryngeal tissues. [HPO:probinson]

Generalized (unlocalized) atrophy affecting muscles of the limbs in both proximal and distal locations. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from upper limbs

Def: Atrophy of the muscles that are responsible for moving the scapula, which are the levator scapulae, the infraspinatus muscle, the teres major, the teres minor, and the supraspinatus muscle. [HPO:curators]
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy. [HPO:curators]
Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature. [HPO:curators]
Generalized degenerative changes of the fat tissue. [HPO:curators]
Progressive spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem. [HPO:curators]
Chronic muscle inflammation accompanied by muscle weakness. [PMID:19349710]
Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed. [HPO:probinson]
Lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Weakness of long finger extensor muscles
Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge

Def: Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds. [HPO:probinson]

Chronic accumulation and overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans on the mucous membranes of the mouth, generally manifested as associated with creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks, occasionally spreading to the gums, tonsils, palate or oropharynx. []
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane. [HPO:probinson]

Anterior open bite is a malocclusion characterized by a gap between the anterior teeth (incisors), that is, by a deficiency in the normal vertical overlap between antagonist incisal edges when the posterior teeth are in occlusion. [HPO:ibailleulforestier, PMID:27615261]
Interruption of the innervation of the diaphragm. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development. [HPO:curators]
Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm. [HPO:probinson]
Absence or underdevelopment of the maxilla. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Enlarged epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger with respect to age-dependent norms. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Small epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger with respect to age-dependent norms. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Triangular epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the little finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the little finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the little finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the little finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger with respect to age-dependent norms. [HPO:curators]

Def: Fragmented appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger. [HPO:curators]

Def: Irregular radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger. [HPO:curators]

Def: Bullet-shaped phalanx refers to a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally . Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction. This term is used if the middle phalanx of the 5th finger is affected. [HPO:curators]

Phenotype: Broad middle phalanx of the 5th finger
Def: Increased width of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger. [HPO:curators]

Def: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger. [HPO:curators]

Def: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger
Def: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement. [HPO:probinson]
