Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct. [HPO:probinson]
Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac. [HPO:probinson]
Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx. [HPO:probinson]
A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa. [HPO:probinson]
A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone. [HPO:probinson]
Both lungs have three lobes. Normally, the left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three lobes. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the blood. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate. [HPO:probinson]
Pain in the lower back and hip radiating in the distribution of the sciatic nerve. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17872935]
Abnormal response to arachidonic acid as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of arachidonic acid. [DDD:wouwehand]
Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ristocetin. [DDD:wouwehand]
Abnormal response to thrombin or thrombin mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thrombin (or thrombin mimetics). [DDD:wouwehand]
Low platelet count following administration of unfractionated or (less commonly) low-molecular weight heparin. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16928996]
Decreased cell membrane concentration of the glycoprotein complex Ib-IX-V. [DDD:wouwehand, PMID:10605725]

An acute form of disseminated intravascular coagulation. Acute DIC can occur following sudden exposure of blood to procoagulants, with the compensatory hemostatic mechanisms becoming overwhelmed. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased cell membrane concentration of glycoprotein VI. [DDD:wouwehand]
Decreased cell membrane concentration of P2Y12 receptor. [DDD:wouwehand, PMID:14755328]
Abnormal bleeding of the umbilical stump following separation of the cord at approximately 7-10 days after birth. [DDD:akelly]
Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye. [HPO:probinson]
Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid. [HPO:probinson]
Bleeding sufficiently severe as to require red cell transfusion (WHO Grade 3 or 4). [DDD:akelly]

Phenotype: Bleeding with minor or no trauma
Def: Significant bleeding or hemorrhage without significant precipitating factor. [DDD:kfreson]
Significant maternal haemorrhage/blood loss following deilvery of a child. [DDD:akelly]
A reduced concentration of vitamin K. []

Phenotype: Impaired thromboxane A2 agonist-induced platelet aggregation
Def: Abnormal response to thromboxane as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thromboxane A2 receptor agonists. [DDD:wouwehand]
Bleeding beneath the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid. [DDD:akelly]
Increased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood. [DDD:akelly]
Decreased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Qualitatively abnormal fibrinogen. [DDD:akelly]

Hemoglobin H (HbH) contains four beta-globin chains. It is normally not present at all in blood, but may make up about 1-40 percent of all hemoglobin in HbH disease, a subform of alpha thalassemia. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21345100]

Hemoglobin F (HbF) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin gamma chains. It is the main form of hemoglobin in the fetus during the last seven months of intrauterine development and in the half year of postnatal life. In adults it normally makes up less than one percent of all hemoglobin. This term refers to an increase in HbF above this limit. In beta thalassemia major, it may represent over 90 percent of all hemoglobin, and in beta thalassemia minor it may make up between 0.5 to 4 percent. [HPO:probinson]

Hemoglobin A (HbA) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin beta chains. HbA is normally the main adult hemoglobin, representing about 96-98 percent of all hemoglobin. This term represents a decreased in the proportion of HbA below this limit, and can be seen in various forms of thalassemia. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the ratio of production of beta globin to that of alpha globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of beta thalassemia. [HPO:probinson, PMID:1060068]
A reduction in the ratio of production of alpha globin to that of beta globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of alpha thalassemia. [HPO:probinson]
Missing radius bone on one side only associated with congenital failure of development. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Shortening of all phalanges of fingers
Def: Abnormal reduction in length affecting all phalanges. [HPO:probinson]
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region. [HPO:probinson]
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the thoracic region. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the extensor digitorum longus muscles, which mediate extension of the toes. [HPO:probinson]
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the fifth toe. [HPO:probinson]
Bending or curvature of a fourth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe). [HPO:probinson]
Accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. [HPO:probinson]

A type of pleural effusion with a transudate (extravascular fluid with low protein content and a low specific gravity). Pleural effusions can be classified as transudates or exudates based on Light's criteria, which classify an effusion as exudate if one or more of the following are present: (1) the ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5, (2) the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH is greater than 0.6, or (3) the pleural fluid LDH level is greater than two thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH. [DDD:tkuijpers, HPO:probinson, PMID:16623208]

A type of pleural effusion with a exudate (extravascular fluid that has exuded out of a tissue or its capillaries due to injury or inflammation). Pleural effusions can be classified as transudates or exudates based on Light's criteria, which classify an effusion as exudate if one or more of the following are present: (1) the ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5, (2) the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH is greater than 0.6, or (3) the pleural fluid LDH level is greater than two thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH. [DDD:tkuijpers, HPO:probinson, PMID:16623208]

Phenotype: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex I
Def: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex I, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex III
Def: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased activity of mitochondrial ATP synthase complex
Def: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial proton-transporting ATP synthase complex, which makes ATP via oxidative phosphorylation, and is sometimes described as Complex V of the electron transport chain. [HPO:probinson]
Proximal mislocalization of the big toe from its normal position. [HPO:probinson]
Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of proximal phalanx of toe. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of third finger
Def: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the third finger. [HPO:probinson]
Increased length of the superior cerebellar peduncle. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased concentration of urate in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased concentration of total carnitine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes. [HPO:probinson]
A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between fingers 3 and 4. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T12 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front). [HPO:probinson]
An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L2 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front). [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of SO3(2-), i.e., sulfite, in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of thiosulfate(2-) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) that affects blood vessels that are smaller than arteries, i.e., arterioles, venules, and capilllaries. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9366584]

Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) is and interstitial lung abnormalitiy characterized histopathologically by plugs of granulation tissue lying within small airways, alveolar ducts, and alveoli and by chronic inflammatory cell infiltration in alveolar walls. Patients with BOOP generally present with subacute illness, including shortness of breath, fever, malaise, and weight loss. [DDD:tkuijpers, HPO:probinson, PMID:20858818]
Inflammation and fibrosis of the bronchioles leading to partial or complete obstruction of these airways. [HPO:probinson]
Acute inflammation of the lung due to an infection. [DDD:tkuijpers]
Inflammation of the bronchioles. [DDD:tkuijpers]
An acute episode of pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract. [HPO:probinson]
Lung parenchymal involvement with lymphoma. [DDD:tkuijpers]
Diffuse benign transformation of the hepatic parenchyma into small regenerative nodules with minimal or no fibrosis. [PMID:21472097]

The presence of multiple granulomas in the liver as based on pathological examination. Granulomas are small 0.5 to 2 mm collections of modified macrophages called epithelioid cells usually surrounded by lymphocytes. [HPO:probinson]

A lymphoproliferative abnormality of the intestine characterized by numerous visible mucosal nodules measuring up to, and rarely exceeding, 0.5 cm in diameter Histologically, hyperplastic lymphoid follicles with large germinal centres are seen in the lamina propria and superficial submucosa. There is enlargement of the mucosal B cell follicles caused by hyperplasia of the follicle centres; surrounded by a normal appearing mantle zone. Disease may involve the stomach, the entire small intestine, and the large intestine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21481240]

Phenotype: Unilateral hypoplasia of pectoralis major muscle
Def: Hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the pectoralis minor on only one side of the chest. [HPO:probinson]
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the substantia nigra. [HPO:probinson]

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from a defect in the production of spermatozoa in the testes. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20514278]

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from post-testicular obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20514278]

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality diagnosed with hypo-gonadotropic-hypogonadism. The diagnosis is made on the basis of low LH and FSH levels and low or normal testosterone levels. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20514278]
History of repeated intermittent involuntary muscle contractions that were painful. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of citrulline in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A reduced concentration of copper in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An elevated concentration of luteinizing hormone in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Amyloid deposition in the walls of leptomeningeal and cortical arteries, arterioles, and less often capillaries and veins of the central nervous system. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21519520]

An exaggerated whealing tendency when the skin is stroked, that is, formation of red, itchy bumps and lines on the skin as a result of pressure on the skin (for instance, stroking the skin with a pen or tongue depressor). [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally low glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid. [HPO:probinson]
Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient lethargy. [HPO:probinson]
Replacement of bone marrow by fibrous tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Partial or complete loss of hearing following ingestion of aminoglycoside antibiotics. [HPO:probinson, PMID:2669624]
An increased concentration of homovanillic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:27830764]
An increased concentration of vanillylmandelic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of dopamine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Gallstones composed primarily of cholesterol, usually about 2-3 cm in length with an oval form and a yellow or green/brown color. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12950109, PMID:16844493]
A type of pigment gallstone that is hard and black, containing calcium carbonate and calcium phosphates. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12950109]
A type of pigment gallstone that is brown, containing calcium fatty acids. These stones are softer than black pigment gallstones. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12950109]
Failure of formation of the lumen of the gallbladder, often associated with gallbladder hypoplasia. [HPO:probinson]
Clay colored stools lacking bile pigment. [HPO:probinson]
Formation of abnormal bony tissue within muscle tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Formation of abnormal bony tissue within tendon tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Formation of abnormal bony tissue within ligament tissue. [HPO:probinson]

A bulging of the interatrial septum towards one side. In adults, atrial septal aneurysm can be defined as a protrusion of the aneurysm of >10 mm beyond the plane of the atrial septum as measured by transesophageal echocardiography. [HPO:probinson, PMID:7758185]

Increased activity of coagulation factor V, Factor V, which is activated to factor Va by means of minute amounts of thrombin (and inactivated by larger amounts of thrombin). Activated factor V (fVa) is a cofactor in the formation of the prothrombinase complex. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally increased level of blood lactate following a meal. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of glucose in the blood following a meal. [HPO:probinson]
A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others. [HPO:probinson]
EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with repetitive generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec. [HPO:jalbers]
Affective auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context. [HPO:probinson]
A subjective feeling that an experience which is occurring for the first time has been experienced before. [HPO:probinson]
A subjective feeling that an experience which has occurred before is being experienced for the first time. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: EEG with central focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the central region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:jalbers]

Phenotype: EEG with frontal focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the frontal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:jalbers]

Phenotype: EEG with occipital focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the occipital region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:jalbers]

Phenotype: EEG with parietal focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the parietal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:jalbers]

Phenotype: EEG with temporal focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the temporal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the central region. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the frontal region. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the occipital region. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the parietal region. [HPO:jalbers]
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the temporal region. [HPO:jalbers]
Complete dislocation of the lens of the eye. [HPO:probinson]
Persistence of blood flow through the ductus venosus for longer than the normal time after birth. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16449256]

A congenital defect of the vasculature such that there is a shunt (by-pass) of blood directly from the portal vein to the vena cava (i.e., the blood from the portal vein is not filtered through the liver). [HPO:probinson]
Elevated concentration of galactose in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Elevated concentration of galactose in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of ornithine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tissues of the larynx. [HPO:probinson]
A benign tumor of the liver of presumably epithelial origin. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally increased concentration of cortisol in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of a lipoma in the region of the sacrum. [HPO:probinson]

Multiple, localized or widespread, asymptomatic or inflammatory dermal cysts involving the pilosebaceous units. Lesions can appear anywhere on the body, but steatocystoma multiplex is more commonly involved with those areas of the skin with a high density of developed pilosebaceous units (e.g., the axilla, groin, neck, and proximal extremities). [HPO:probinson, PMID:20631281]
Wasting of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the muscle in the anterior part of the neck that acts to flex and rotate the head. [HPO:probinson]
Wasting of the pectoral muscles, i.e., of the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor. [HPO:probinson]

Corneal guttata are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. The presence of focal thickenings of Descemet's membrane histologically named guttae. Cornea guttata can be easily diagnosed in vivo and ex vivo by means of specular microscopy as it gives dark areas where no endothelial cells are visible. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10611102, PMID:11222329]

Presence of folds in the Descemet membrane, which is the basement membrane of the endothelial (inner) cell layer of the cornea. Descemet membrane folds are generally a manifestation of inflammation or edema of the cornea. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling of the stroma of cornea. [HPO:probinson]
A type of asthma in which aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that inhibit cyclooxygen-ase 1 (COX-1) exacerbate bronchoconstriction. [PMID:12743549]

Seesaw nystagmus is a type of pendular nystagmus where a half cycle consists of the elevation and intorsion of one eye, concurrently with the depression and extortion of the fellow eye. In the other half cycle, there is an inversion of the ocular movements. [HPO:probinson]
A visual defect characterized by the inability to see as clearly in bright light as in dim light. The word hemeralopia literally means day blindness. [HPO:probinson]

A kind of focal dystonia characterized by forceful contractions of the face, jaw, and/or tongue causing difficulty in opening and closing the mouth and often affecting chewing and speech. [HPO:probinson]

A form of focal dystonia that affects the vocal cords, associated with involuntary contractions of the vocal cords causing interruptions of speech and affecting the voice quality and often leading to patterned, repeated breaks in speech. [HPO:probinson]
An extreme form of generalized edema with widespread and massive edema due to effusion of fluid into the extracellular space. [HPO:probinson]
Hypoglycermia following a meal (or more generally, after intake of glucose). [HPO:probinson]
A reduced concentration of calcitriol in the blood. Calcitriol is also known as 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3. [HPO:probinson]
A reduced concentration of calcifediol in the blood. Calcifediol is also known as calcidiol, 25-hydroxycholecalciferol and 25-Hydroxyvitamin D3. [HPO:probinson]

Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the choroid. The classic appearance of choroidal melanoma is a pigmented dome-shaped or collar button-shaped tumor with an associated exudative retinal detachment. Choroidal melanoma is usually pigmented, but can be variably pigmented and even amelanotic (non-pigmented). [HPO:probinson, PMID:22557869]
Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the ciliary body. [HPO:probinson]
A type of melanoma that is flat and irregular in shape and color, with different shades of black and brown. [HPO:probinson]
A type of melanoma that starts as a raised area that is usually dark blackish-blue or bluish-red but may not have any color. [HPO:probinson]

A subtype of melanoma in situ that typically develops on sun-damaged skin. The lesion is typically a large, irregularly pigmented macule that has developed from an ordinary lentigo (a small pigmented spot on the skin with a clearly-defined edge). Change to a malignant lentigo typically takes place over 20 years or more, and many patients accept the change as a consequence of aging. [HPO:7734995, HPO:probinson]

A type of cutaneous melanoma localized to the palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma). Acral lentiginous melanoma starts as a slowly-enlarging flat patch of discoloured skin and usually displays a size above 6 mm and often several centimetres or more in diameter upon diagnosis and variable pigmentation with a mixutre of colors including brown, and blue-grey, black and red. The surface of the lesion is initially smooth but later in the course may become thicker and irregular, and may ulcerate or bleed. [HPO:probinson]
Excretion of oligosaccharides conjugated to sialic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Radiographic features include a dilated, radiolucent lesion typically located eccentrically within the metaphyseal portion of the bone, with fluid levels visible on magnetic resonance imaging. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22474093, PMID:7863874]
A benign fluid filled simple cyst of bone filled with serous fluid. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of multiple cystic changes in multiple areas or multiple bones. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of disaccharide in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Excretion of excess amounts of aspartylglucosamine in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of keratan sulfate in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of chondroitin sulfate (CHEBI:37397) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormality of the pupillary light reaction characterized by a marked slowing of the light reaction of usually just one pupil. The pupil tends to be relatively dilated, and there is reduced accommodation. [HPO:probinson]

A personality disorder characterized by impulsive behavior and unpredictable and capricious mood. Affected individuals show a liability to outbursts of emotion and an incapacity to control the behavioural explosions. [HPO:probinson]

A personality disorder characterized by shallow and labile affectivity, self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated expression of emotions, suggestibility, egocentricity, self-indulgence, lack of consideration for others, easily hurt feelings, and continuous seeking for appreciation, excitement and attention. [ICD-10:F60.4]
Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the granular cell layer. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the Purkinje cell layer. [HPO:probinson]
Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates that show positive staining with antibodies against ubiquitin within cells of the brain. [HPO:probinson]
A deviation from the normal odor of the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Dislocation of many joints. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from ectodermal cells that normally form skin cells being left behind in the nervous system during development. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16714456]

A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from the inclusion of ectodermally committed cells at the time of neural tube closure (3rd-5th week of embryogenesis). The capsule of dermoid cysts consists of simple epithelium supported by collagen. In thicker parts, the lining is supplemented with dermis containing hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and apocrine glands. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16714456]

Phenotype: Edema of the dorsum of feet
Def: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the feet. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally reduced amount of creatinine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the parietal cortex. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the occipital cortex. [HPO:probinson]
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of the leg (i.e. the femur). [HPO:probinson]
Increased width of the cross sectional diameter of the fibula. [HPO:probinson, MP:0008159]
A type of glaucoma defined by an open, normal appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure, [HPO:probinson, PMID:11815354]
A type of glaucomatous optic neuropathy in an eye that has evidence of angle closure (i.e. significant iridotrabecular contact). [HPO:probinson, PMID:11815354, UManchester:psergouniotis]
A carcinoma of the endometrium, the mucous lining of the uterus. [HPO:probinson, NCIT:C7558]
Elevation in the concentration of albumin in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A carcinoma of the larynx. [HPO:probinson, NCIT:C4855]

Abnormally increased levels of methemoglobin in the blood. In this form of hemoglobin, there is an oxidized ferric iron (Fe +3) rather than the reduced ferrous form (Fe 2+) that is normally found in hemoglobin. Methemoglobin has a reduced affinity for oxygen, resulting in a reduced ability to release oxygen to tissues. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which inflammation affects the anterior chamber, vitreous, retina or choroid. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the retina or choroid. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the vitreous. [HPO:probinson]
A cancer of the prostate. [HPO:probinson]
A cancer arising in any part of the stomach. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of uracil in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Death of cells in the basal ganglia. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Abnormality of bone marrow stromal cells

Def: Decreased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow. [DDD:akelly]
Decreased number of granulocyte precursors in the bone marrow. [HPO:akelly]
A subtype of ductal pancreatic carcinoma that is thought to originate from squamous metaplasia of pancreatic ductal epithelium. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19079631]

Phenotype: Reduced quantity of Von Willebrand factor
Def: Decreased quantity of von Willebrand factor. [DDD:akelly]
Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two or more of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic. [DDD:akelly]
Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic. [DDD:akelly]
The presence of blood in the pleural space. [HPO:probinson]
Splitting of the retinal layers in the macula. [HPO:probinson]
An decrease in the level of triglycerides in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Inability to experience pleasure activities usually found enjoyable. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced ability of the cornea to respond to stimulation. [HPO:probinson]
Phagocytosis by macrophages of erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets, and their precursors in bone marrow and other tissues. [HPO:probinson]
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the intracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall. [HPO:probinson]
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the external carotid artery wall. [HPO:probinson]
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the common carotid artery wall. [HPO:probinson]
A dilatation (balooning or bulging out of the vessel wall) of a carotid artery. [HPO:probinson]
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints. [HPO:probinson]
Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20575652]
A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss. [HPO:probinson]
Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib. [HPO:probinson]
Habitual biting of one's own fingernails. [HPO:probinson]
Habitual clasping and squeezing of the hands. [HPO:probinson]
Habitual repetitive movement of the body. [HPO:probinson]
An increase in heart rate with standing of 30 beats per minute or more. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9244228]

A tumor arising from glia in the central nervous system with macroscopic regions of necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopically, glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by regions of pseudopalisading necrosis, pleomorphic nuclei and cells, and microvascular proliferation. [HPO:probinson, NCIT:C3058, PMID:10841526]

Poor anticoagulant response to activated protein C. A plasma is termed 'APC resistant' when the addition of exogenous APC fails to prolong its clotting time in an activated partial thromboplastin time assay. [HPO:probinson, PMID:14976057]
Reduced ability of the natural killer cell to function in the adaptive immune response. [HPO:probinson]
A squamous cell carcinoma that originates in the oropharnyx. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of multiple hyperplastic polyps in the colon. Hyperplastic polyps are generally about 5 mm in size and show hyperplastic mucosal proliferation. [HPO:probinson]
An elevated concentration of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL) in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

Injury to the median nerve caused by its entrapment at the wrist as it traverses through the carpal tunnel. Clinically, constrictive median neuropathy is characterized by pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the median nerve distribution of the hand. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at elbow
Def: An entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel (in the elbow) characterized by numbness in the ring and little fingers and weakness of the intrinsic muscles in the hand. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of protoporphyrins in erythrocytes. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18760763]
Excessive vomiting in early pregnancy, leading to the loss of 5% or more of body weight. [HPO:probinson, OMIM:603373]
A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells. [HPO:probinson]
A type of T-cell lymphoma that exhibits malignant infiltration of the skin. [HPO:probinson]
A type of T-cell lymphoma that is characterized by so-called hallmark cells with a pleomorphic appearance that express the CD30 antigen, are lobulated, and have indented nuclei. [HPO:probinson]
Transient episodes of weakness of the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body. [HPO:probinson]
Uneven rhythm of breathing. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormal pattern of respiration characterized by cycles of respiration that are increasingly deeper then shallower with possible periods of apnea. Affected patients may display a 10 to 20 second episode of hypoventilation or apnea, followed by respiration of increased depth and frequency over the course of about one minute. The cycle repeats every 45 seconds to 3 minutes. [HPO:probinson]
A type of tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that secretes excess insulin and can result in hypoglycemia. [HPO:probinson, NCIT:C95598]

The presence of more than 5 juvenile polyps of the colon. The term juvenile polyps refer to a special histopathology and not the age of onset as the polyp might be diagnosed at all ages. The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17768394, PMID:25022750]
A type of headache characterized by repeated attacks of unilateral pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes and associated with local autonomic signs. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21912573]
A fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails that tends to cause the nails to thicken, discolor, disfigure, and split. [HPO:probinson]
Recurrent infection involving the vulva, vagina, and adjacent crural areas, whereby the causative agent belongs to the genus Candida. [HPO:probinson]
Any structural anomaly of the acrosome resulting in a round sperm head. [HPO:probinson, MP:0002686]
An abnormal reduction in the mobility of ejaculated sperm. [HPO:probinson]
A lack of mobility of ejaculated sperm. [HPO:probinson]

Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is a lethal myeloproliferative disease of young childhood characterized clinically by overproduction of myelomonocytic cells and by the in vitro phenotype of hematopoietic progenitor hypersensitivity to granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18954903]
An abnormal reduction in the volume of fluid filtered out of plasma through glomerular capillary walls into Bowman's capsules per unit of time. [HP:probinson, PMID:25710660]
An abnormal rise in the volume of water filtered out of plasma through glomerular capillary walls into Bowman's capsules per unit of time. [HP:probinson]
The deposition of calcium phosphate microliths within the seminiferous tubules. [HPO:probinson]

An entrapment neuropathy of the suprascapular nerve, presenting with shoulder weakness confined to the supraspinatus muscle (this muscle initiates shoulder abduction) or to the infraspinatus (this muscle externally rotates the arm), as well as with pain in the posterior part of the shoulder and upper periscapular region. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of porphobilinogen in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11861450]

A type of soft tissue sarcoma with a histological appearance reminiscent of alveoli because of its reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells, which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue. [HPO:probinson, PMID:11244503]
An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral. [HPO:probinson]

The presence of multiple epithelioid cell granulomas consist of highly differentiated mononuclear phagocytes (epithelioid cells and giant cells) and lymphocytes, not exhibiting caseation (a form of necrosis in which the tissue changes into a dry, amorphous mass said to resemble cheese). [HPO:probinson]
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the tibial region. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15265795]
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the arachnoid. [HPO:probinson]
A breach of the capsule of the spleen. [HPO:probinson]
Persistence of immune complexes in the blood circulation. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced number of primary teeth. [HPO:probinson]

A type of headache that last hours with continuous pain of mild or moderate intensity, bilateral location, a pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality and that is not aggravated by routine physical activity such as walking or climbing stairs. [HPO:probinson]

A type of retinal detachment associated with a retinal tear, that is, with a break in the retina that allows fluid to pass from the vitreous space into the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. [HPO:probinson]

A type of retinal detachment arising from damage to the outer blood-retinal barrier that allows fluid to access the subretinal space and separate the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium. [HPO:probinson, ORCID:0000-0003-0986-4123]
Decreased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG). [HPO:probinson]
Blood clot formed within muscle tissue following leakage of blood into the tissue. [HPO:probinson]
A type of agranulocytosis related to ingestion of a specific medication. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of chloride in the sweat. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of urocanic acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Increased plasma concentrations of chylomicrons, the large lipid droplet (up to 100 mm in diameter) of reprocessed lipid synthesized in epithelial cells of the small intestine and containing triacylglycerols, cholesterol esters, and several apolipoproteins. [HPO:probinson, MP:0009699]
Absence of transferrin, a protein that transports iron, in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormal increase in intracellular lipid droplets In a muscle. The number and size of these drops can increase with somd disorders of lipid metabolism affecting muscle. See PMID 20691590 for histological images. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20691590]
Atrophy of the levator palpebrae superioris, the extraocular muscle that elevates the superior eyelid. [HPO:probinson]
Atrophy of the superior rectus, the extraocular muscle whose primary function is to elevate the globe. [HPO:probinson]
Development of the reproductive system is inconsistent with the chromosomal sex. [HPO:probinson, MP:0005652]
Reduced ability to control the movement of the eye associated with damage to the third cranial nerve (the oculomotor nerve). [HPO:probinson]
Anosmia for one particular odor. [HPO:probinson]
Increased time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex). [HPO:probinson, PMID:23677846]
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located inferior to the isoelectric line. [HPO:probinson]
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located superior to the isoelectric line. [HPO:probinson]
A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17272319]

Phenotype: Abnormal axonemal organization of respiratory motile cilia
Def: Abnormal arrangement of the structures of the axoneme, which is the cytoskeletal structure that forms the inner core of the motile cilium and displays a canonical 9+2 microtubular pattern of motile cilia studded with dynein arms. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19606528]

Phenotype: Absent inner and outer dynein arms
Def: Complete absence of the dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, that is, absence of the inner and the outer dynein arms, which normally are situated inside and outside of the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19606528]

Phenotype: Abnormal central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia
Def: A structural anomaly of the two central microtubules of motile cilia with a 9+2 microtubuluar configuration. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19200523]

Phenotype: Absent central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia
Def: Absence of the two central microtubules of motile cilia with a 9+2 microtubuluar configuration. [HPO:probinson]

A deviation from the normally well coordinated pattern of intracellular and intercellular synchrony of motile cilia. Dyskinetic cilia usually beat out of synchrony relative to neighboring cilia. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19606528]
A periodic beat-to-beat variation in the amplitude or shape of the T wave in an EKG. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17592081]

Phenotype: Absent respiratory ciliary axoneme radial spokes
Def: Absence of the radial spokes of the axoneme of the respiratory cilium. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19606528]
A liposarcoma that contains myxomatous tissue. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue. [HPO:probinson]
Intermittent episodes of increased resistance to the passage of air in the upper airway. [HPO:probinson]
The J wave is a positive convex deflection that occurs at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment, the J-point. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19561994]

Phenotype: Increased carotid artery intimal medial thickness
Def: An increase in the combined thickness of the intima and media of the carotid artery. [HPO:probinson, PMID:9878640]

Inflammation of the flexor digitorum tendon, often associated with the Kanavel signs: (i) finger held in slight flexion, (ii) fusiform swelling, (iii) tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath, and (iv) pain with passive extension of the digit. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16443118]
An abnormally reduced concentration of glycine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced concentration of serine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
A form of amyloidosis that affects the liver. [HPO:probinson]
Extravasation of chyle into the peritoneal cavity. [HPO:probinson]

An exanthema consisting of widespread pink-to-red macules (flat spots of 2-10 mm in diameter) or papules (red bumps) that blanch with pressure. The macules and papules may cluster and merge to form sheets over several days. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced size of the Distal epiphysis of femur. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced size of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia. [HPO:probinson]
Decreased secretion of luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus. [HPO:probinson]
A congenital defect with an abnormal joining of the gums of the upper and lower jaw. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19858676]
Reduced diameter of the middle phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced diameter of the distal phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced diameter of the proximal phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Increased length of the middle phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Increased length of the distal phalanx of finger. [HPO:probinson]
Failure of the ureter to undergo development. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal transferrin isoform profile consistent with a type II congenital disorder of glycosylation. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15105360, PMID:22516080]
Infection of the brain parenchyma with herpes simplex virus, resulting in inflammation of the brain parenchyma with neurologic dysfunction. [HPO:probinson, PMID:27106239]
Ribs that are increased in width and taper to the posterior ends. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20504305]
A reduced level of the complement component C9 in circulation. [https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/135478-overview]
An increased number of circulating monocytes. [HPO:probinson]
An decreased number of circulating monocytes. [HPO:probinson]

Bony swelling of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10531070, PMID:17488856, PMID:9709182]

Bony swelling of the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10531070, PMID:9709182]
A neoplasm containing histiocytes. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the sacroiliac joint, generally accompanied by lower back pain. [HPO:probinson]

A distinct type of headache characterized by piercing, throbbing, or electric-shock-like chronic pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears, usually on one side. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21569290]
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the abdomen. [HPO:probinson]
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the arms and legs. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of 2-hydroxyglutaric acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20847235]
Inflammation surrounding hair follicles. [HPO:probinson]
Myoclonus that occurs during the initial phases of sleep. [HPO:probinson]

A myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm which is characterized by persistent monocytosis, absence of a Philadelphia chromosome and BCR/ABL fusion gene, fewer than 20 percent blasts in the bone marrow and blood, myelodysplasia, and absence of PDGFRA or PDGFRB rearrangement. [NCIT:C3178]
Compression of the celiac artery. [HPO:probinson]
An odontogenic tumor of the cementum of tooth. [HPO:probinson]
A vascular tumor of the skin and subcutaneous tissues and characterized by slow angiomatous proliferation. [HPO:probinson, PMID:2644316]
An abnormal regulation of the sweat glands by the sympathetic nervous system associated with abnormal perspiration. [HPO:probinson]
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in large bile ducts outside the liver. [HPO:probinson]
An increase in the number of calories used per unit time. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction in the number of calories used per unit time. [HPO:probinson]
A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of less than 10 mm diameter. [HPO:probinson]
A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of more than 10 mm diameter. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally reduced concentration of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron, in the blood. [HPO:probinson]
Isolated patches of hardened skin (scleroderma). [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased galactosylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: A reduction in the amount of galactose residues of N-glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased sialylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Decreased addition of sialic acids to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased sialylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Increased addition of sialic acids to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased fucosylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Decreased addition of fucose sugar units to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased fucosylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Increased addition of fucose sugar units to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased mannosylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Reduced addition of mannose to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased mannosylation of N-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Increased addition of mannose to N-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased fucosylation of O-linked protein glycosylation
Def: A reduction of the addition of fucose sugar units to O-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Increased fucosylation of O-linked protein glycosylation
Def: Increased addition of fucose sugar units to O-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: Decreased sialylation of O-linked protein glycosylation
Def: An reduced addition of sialic acids to O-linked glycans. [HPO:probinson]
A decreased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

Projection of the tip of the dens more than 5 mm above a line joining the hard palate to the posterior lip of the foramen magnum (Chamberlain's line) or the tip of the dens is greater than 7 mm above McGregor's line (the back of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital squama). [HPO:probinson, PMID:10084535]
Bony defects situated along the cranial suture lines or at the junction of the bone plates of the skull. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of concavity or convexity of the face when viewed in profile. [PMID:19125436]
Large or prominent malar surface of the zygomatic bone of the skull, which is convex and forms the prominence of the 'cheek bones'. [ORCID:0000-0001-5889-4463, PMID:19125436]

Abnormally anterior positioning of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased convexity of the face, or increased nasolabial angle. The midface includes the maxilla, the cheeks, the zygomas, and the infraorbital and perialar regions of the face [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125436]
Edema (swelling) of the bulbar conjunctiva. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormal smallness of the lens. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced carnitine O-palmitoyltransferase level, leading to a reduced activity of the reaction: palmitoyl-CoA + L-carnitine = CoA + L-palmitoylcarnitine. [HPO:probinson]
A delay in the development of skills required to feed oneself in the toddler period (between one and three years of age). [HPO:probinson]
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the left side of the heart to the right. [HPO:mhaendel]
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from both right side of the heart to the left and vice versa. [HPO:mhaendel]
Aplasia of the hallux, that is, a development defect such that the big toe does not develop. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the large airways of the lung with rapid onset and short course usually associated with cough, mucus production, shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness. [HPO:probinson]
Muscular hypotonia of one or more limbs. [HPO:probinson]
A small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in jaw. [HPO:probinson]
Allergy to iodine contrast media used in radiological studies. [HPO:probinson]
An allergy experienced at a particular time of year when trees or grasses pollinate and elicit an allergic reaction. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques in the aorta. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16818829]
An abnormal accumulation of interstitial fluid in the soft tissues of the limbs. [HPO:probinson]

A type of ulcer that is caused when an area of skin is subject to pressure over a prolonged period of time, ranging in range in severity from patches of discolored skin to open wounds that expose the underlying bone or muscle. The most common sites are the sacrum, coccyx, heels and the hips. [HPO:probinson]
A greater than normal concentration of 2-oxoglutaric acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A lower than normal concentration of 2-oxoglutaric acid in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A lower than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
A greater than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine. [HPO:probinson]

A type of spastic paraparetic gait in which the muscle tone in the adductors is marked. It is characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use. [HPO:probinson]
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal medulla (innermost part of the kidney). [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal cortex (the outer portion of the kidney between the renal capsule and the renal medulla). [HPO:probinson]

A type of anemia resulting from suppression of erythropoiesis with little or no abnormality of leukocyte or platelet production. Erythroblasts are virtually absent in bone marrow; however, leukocyte and platelet production show little or no reduction. [HPO:probinson]
The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal. [HPO:probinson]
Onset of adrenarche at an earlier age than usual. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of a V-shaped indentation (notch) in the primary central incisor. [HPO:probinson]
Wasting or decrease in size of all or part of the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level. [HPO:probinson]
Abnormally reduced blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally high level of blood oxygen. [HPO:probinson]
Amniotic fluid containing the earliest stools of a mammalian infant. [HPO:probinson]
Congenital lack of the skin of prepuce of penis, that is, of the double-layered fold of skin and mucous membrane that covers the glans penis. [HPO:probinson]
Overgrowth of the choroid plexus. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16523225]
The inability of the colon to modify stool to an acceptable consistency and move the stool from the cecum to the rectosigmoid area at least once every three days. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23449085]
An inflammation of the choroid and retina. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432, PMID:16196117]
An ulcer of the colon due to pressure and irritation from retained fecal masses. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432, PMID:7065551]

Optic disc drusen are acellular, calcified deposits within the optic nerve head. Optic disc drusen are congenital and developmental anomalies of the optic nerve head, representing hyaline-containing bodies that, over time, appear as elevated, lumpy irregularities on the anterior portion of the optic nerve. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22787500, PMID:23658477, PMID:30524490]

An increased degree of femoral version, which is defined as the angular difference between axis of femoral neck and transcondylar axis of the knee. Thus, femoral anteversion is an inward twisting of the femur that causes the knees and feet to turn inward. [HPO:probinson, ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432, PMID:32579722]
Protruding heel bone, or calcaneus. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Underdevelopment of the cerebral white matter. [HPO:probinson]
Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation. [HPO:probinson]
Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A failure to meet one or more age-related milestones of social behavior. [HPO:probinson]
Reduction in length of the ventral (lower) skin of prepuce of penis. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Coronary disease that has not progressed to the point of causing significant occlusion (blockage) of the coronary arteries. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Reduced motility through the sphincter of Oddi, resulting in impedance of bile and pancreatic juice flow from the common bile duct into the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced motility of the gallbladder with reduced emptying fraction. [HPO:probinson, PMID:12095476, PMID:17761125]
A reduced concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate(2-) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). 5-methyltetrahydrofolate is the active folate metabolite. [HPO:probinson]
Inflammation of the synovial membrane of the sacroiliac joint. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]

Constipation for longer than three months with fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, straining, lumpy or hard stools, and a sensation of anorectal obstruction or incomplete defecation. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Constipation of sudden onset and lasting for less than three months. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A feeling of uneasiness and restlessness in the legs after going to bed (sometimes causing insomnia). [HPO:probinson]
A chronic loss of wrist joint motion on the right and left sides. [HPO:probinson]
A chronic loss of wrist joint motion on one side only. [HPO:probinson]
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of medium-sized (muscular or distributive) arteries. [HPO:probinson]
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of small arteries. [HPO:probinson]
A headache disorder that occurs exclusively at night, waking the affected individual from sleep. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20585827, PMID:23832130]
A structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
The presence of bacteria in the urine. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Involuntary and irregular twitches of the chin. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16816905]
An above normal level of saturation of serum transferrin with iron. [HPO:probinson]
A below normal level of saturation of serum transferrin with iron. [HPO:probinson]
An increased level of iron in liver tissues. [HPO:probinson, PMID:10922422, PMID:14668426]

Longstanding impairment in ventilation such that the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is elevated above the upper limit of the reference range (more than 45 mm Hg), with a normal or near-normal pH secondary to renal compensation and an elevated serum bicarbonate levels (more than30 mEq/L). [HPO:probinson]

Sudden onset of impairment in ventilation such that the removal of carbon dioxide by the respiratory system is less than the production of carbon dioxide in the tissues, leading to an elevation of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) above the normal limits (more than 45 mm Hg) with an accompanying acidemia (pH less than 7.35). [HPO:probinson]
Infantile spasms represent a subset of \epileptic spasms\". Infantile Spasms are epileptic spasms starting in the first year of life (infancy)." [HPO:ihelbig]

An ophthalmologic sign in young children resulting from upward-gaze paresis. In this condition, the eyes appear driven downward, the sclera may be seen between the upper eyelid and the iris, and part of the lower pupil may be covered by the lower eyelid. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17030938]
Wasting of the tongue. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Complete obstruction of a carotid artery. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
The presence of normal overall immunoglobulin levels with deficiency of specific immunoglobulins directed against pneumococci. [HPO:probinson]

A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22505778]
Bony fusion of the mandibular condyle to the base of the skull, resulting in limitation of jaw opening. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Noises from the temporomandibular joint during mandibular movement (e.g., chewing). Temporomandibular joint crepitus is often described as a clicking, popping, grating sound. [HPO:probinson]
A venous angioma of the frontal lobe of the brain. [HPO:probinson]

An anomaly of the invaginations of the surface membrane that form the open canalicular system (OCS). The OCS serve as the pathway for transport of substances into the cells and as conduits for the discharge of alpha granule products secreted during the platelet release reaction. [HPO:probinson, PMID:1760557]
Inflammation of the spinal cord. [HPO:probinson]
An arachnoid cyst located at the margin of the cerebellum and pons. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
An arachnoid cyst located within the ventricular system. [HPO:probinson, PMID:8951893]

An arachnoid cyst that progressively enlarges from an abnormality in the membrane of Liliequist or in the interpeduncular cistern, and typically, expands from the prepontine space, displacing the floor of the third ventricle upwards, the pituitary stalk and optic chiasm upwards and forwards, and the mammillary bodies upwards and backwards. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21586175]
Inflammation of adipose tissue. [HPO:probinson]
An anomaly of the intracellular membrane complexes known as the dense tubular system. [DDD:wouwehand, PMID:1322202]
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the middle cerebral artery. [HPO:probinson]
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the anterior cerebral artery. [HPO:probinson]
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the posterior cerebral artery. [HPO:probinson]
A decrease in the maximum amount of negative pressure a person can generate during an inhalation. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A decrease in the maximum amount of pressure of expired air achieved by a person after a full inspiration. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A complication of pregnancy and delivery in which the umbilical cord wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times. [HPO:probinson]

A separation of the layers within the wall of the descending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space. [HPO:probinson]
A wartlike (with multiple small elevated projections) papule. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormally increased size of the pituitary gland. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Reduced strength of the orbicularis oculi, the circumorbital muscle in the face that closes the eyelid. [HPO:probinson]
A visual anomaly in which images appear distorted. A grid of straight lines appears wavy and parts of the grid may appear blank. [HPO:probinson]

An abnormally decreased amount of thyroxin-binding globulin (TBG) in blood. TBG is responsible for carrying the thyroid hormones thyroxine (T4) and 3,5,3'-triiodothyronine (T3) in the bloodstream. [HPO:probinson]
An increased amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22327705, PMID:23838695]
Reduced ability to flex the femur, that is, to pull the knee upward. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
An abnormally decreased amount of catalase level. [HPO:probinson]
Underdeveloped posterior communicating artery. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]

Increased dimensions of the Virchow-Robin spaces (also known as perivascular spaces), which surround the walls of vessels as they course from the subarachnoid space through the brain parenchyma. Perivascular spaces are commonly microscopic, and not visible on conventional neuroimaging. This term refers to an increase of size of these spaces such that they are visible on neuroimaging (usually magnetic resonance imaging). The dilatations are regular cavities that always contain a patent artery. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432, PMID:17620468, PMID:23867200, PMID:25564639]
Congenital absence of the optic nerve. [HPO:probinson]

A form of telangiectasis characterized by a central elevated red dot the size of a pinhead, representing an arteriole, with numerous small blood vessels that radiate out thereby resembling the legs of a spider. Characteristically, compression of the central arteriole causes the entire lesion to blanch, and the lesion quickly refills once the compression is released. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22356347]

Reluctance or refusal of a child to be breastfed or eat, manifested as gagging, vomiting, turning head away from food, or avoidance of sensation in or around the mouth (i.e. toothbrushing or face-washing). [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A deviation from the normal discoid platelet shape. [DD:WHO]
An anomalous location and arrangement of platelet alpha granules. [DDD:wouwehand]
A lack of platelet alpha granules. This typically results in the grey appearance of platelets in giemsa stained blood smears. [HPO:probinson, PMID:3877532]

A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain hemostatic proteins such as fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and growth factors such as platelet-derived growth factor. [HPO:probinson]

A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain adenosine triphosphate (ATP), adenosine diphosphate (ADP), serotonin, calcium, and pyrophosphate, which are secreted when platelets are activated. [DDD:wouwehand]
Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has lasted longer than 3 to 6 months. [HPO:probinson, PMID:1875958]
Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain. [HPO:probinson]

Painful sensations elicited by a nonpainful cutaneous stimulus such as a light touch or gentle stroking over affected areas of the body. Sometimes referred to as hyperpathia or hyperalgesia. Often perceived as an intense burning, dyesthesias may outlast the stimulus by several seconds. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
The presence of circulating autoantibodies to anticardiolipin in the mother. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432, PMID:1495720, PMID:9722063]
A detrimental reaction to the presence of gluten in food, which may include abdominal pain, fatigue, headaches and paresthesia, or celiac disease. [HPO:probinson]
An epidermoid cyst in the armpit. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Hemorrhage between the skull and periosteum of a newborn resulting from rupture of blood vessels that cross the periosteum. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
Thickened nails without deformity. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of hemosiderin in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
An increased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
An decreased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
A deviation from equal (50%) inactivation of each parental X chromosome in maternal cells. [HPO:probinson, PMID:18097476]
Muscle fibers degeneration resulting in fatty replacement of skeletal muscle fibers [HPO:probinson, Neuromics:vstraub]
A lipoma (a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue) located in the conjunctiva. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of varices (enlarged and convoluted blood vessels) in the colon. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16688816]
Presence of an elevated number of projections from nuclei of neutrophils. These projections can have the shape of hooks, tags, or clubs. [HPO:probinson]
A thumbnail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped thumb nail. [HPO:probinson]
Absence of thumb nail. [HPO:probinson]
Absent nail of big toe. [HPO:probinson]
Increased concentration of beta-alanine in the blood. [HPO:probinson]

Phenotype: EEG with centrotemporal focal spike waves
Def: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the centrotemporal region of the brain (also known as the central sulcus), i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave. [HPO:probinson]
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is higher than normal. [HPO:probinson]
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is lower than normal. [HPO:probinson]
The presence of an aortic valve with one instead of the normal three cusps (flaps). [HPO:probinson, PMID:18480095, PMID:20329493]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the hand, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the foot, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the tibia, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the fibula, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the radius, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the ulna, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone. [HPO:probinson]
Edema in the region of the Lower eyelid. [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
First period after the age of 15 years. [HPO:probinson]
A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities. [HPO:probinson]
A partial duplication of the ureter where the duplicated ureters fuse to a single ureter before their insertion into the bladder. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
A complete duplication of the ureter, where the duplicated ureters have separate insertions into the bladder. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]

A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption with bicarbonate loss and resulting acidosis. [HPO:probinson]

Increased numbers of mesangial cells per glomerulus, defined as more than 3 nuclei fully surrounded by matrix in one or more mesangial areas, not including perihilar region, on a standard 3-micron-thick tissue section, best evaluated on periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain. [Eurenomics:fschaefer, KPMP:arosenberg, PMID:32866505]
The presence of complement 3 deposits in the glomerulus. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]

Decreased thickness of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), measured from endothelial to visceral epithelial plasma membrane and mainly attributable to a decrease in thickness of the lamina densa, generally to an overall thickness more than 2 standard deviations less than that of the normal mean GBM thickness for health age- and sex matched individuals. May be focal or diffuse, although the term thin GBMs generally implies thinning of over 50% of GBMs. [HPO:probinson, KPMP:arosenberg, PMID:32866505]
A type of glomerulonephropathy characterized by thickening of the basement membrane and deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
The presence of minimal changes visible by light microscopy but flattened and fused podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy in a person with nephrotic range proteinuria. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
The presence of calcium- and phosphate-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys. [HPO:probinson]
An isolated cyst of the kidney. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
A bilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
One sided hypoplasia of the kidney. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Two sided hypoplasia of the kidney. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
A two-sided form of atrophy of the kidney. [HPO:probinson]
Hematuria that is visible upon inspection of the urine. [HPO:sdoelken]

A form of nephrotic syndrome that does not respond to treatment with steroid medication, defined as persistent proteinuria despite 60mg/m2 or 2mg/kg for 8 weeks, after insuring no infection or non-adherence to medication. [Eurenomics:ewuehl, ORCID:0000-0002-2234-4248, PMID:29910038]
A form of nephrotic syndrome that does not respond to any immunosuppresive treatment. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
Severely increased amount of excretion of protein in the urine, defined as 3.5 grams per day or more in adults and 40 mg per meter-squared body surface area per hour in children. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]

The presence of moderately increased concentrations of albumin in the urine, defined as and albumin-creatinine ratio (ACR) of 30 to 299 mg/gm (3.4 to 34 mg/mmol). [Eurenomics:fschaefer, PMID:30571025]
Mildly increased levels of protein in the urine (150-500 mg per day in adults). [Eurenomics:eweuehl]
Moderately increased levels of protein in the urine (500-1000 mg per day in adults). [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Severely increased levels of protein in the urine (1000-3000 mg per day in adults). [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
An decreased concentration of chloride in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
High urine chloride in the presence of hypochloridemia. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the urine. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
An increased concentration of sodium(1+) in the urine. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the urine in the presence of hyponatremia. [Eurenomics:ewuehl]
An increased concentration of magnesium the urine. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
An decreased concentration of magnesium the urine. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Elevated concentration of SO4(2-), i.e., sulfate, in the urine. [HPO:probinson]
Presence of leukocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Presence of erythrocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine. [Eurenomics:fschaefer, PMID:8856231]
A cyst located along the allantois canal. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Presence of a many diverticula (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder. [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Developmental anomaly in which the vagina, bladder, and rectum fuse resulting in a common channel. [HPO:probinson]
A type of chronic kidney disease with normal or increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR at least 90 mL/min/1.73 m2). [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
A type of chronic kidney disease with mildly reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 60-89 mL/min/1.73 m2). [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
A type of chronic kidney disease with moderately reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 30-59 mL/min/1.73 m2). [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
A type of chronic kidney disease with severely reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 15-29 mL/min/1.73 m2). [Eurenomics:fschaefer]
Deposition of fibrillar material that can be found on all anterior segment structures bathed by aqueous humor. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23157966]

Phenotype: Abnormal suspensory ligament of lens morphology
Def: An anomaly of the suspensory ligament of lens, also known as the ciliary zonule. These ligaments represent a series of fibers connecting the ciliary body and lens of the eye, holding the lens in place. [HPO:probinson]
Tremulousness (trembling) of the lens of the eye. [HPO:probinson, PMID:5472193]

Phenotype: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork
Def: Accumulation of abnormal amounts of pigment within the trabecular meshwork. [HPO:probinson]
Shedding of the pigment granules that normally adhere to the back of the iris into the aqueous humor. [HPO:probinson]
Reduction in the amount of blood flow to the iris. [HPO:probinson]
High urine calcium in the presence of hypocalcemia. [HPO:probinson]
A reduction of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid. [HPO:probinson]

Cerebellar agenesis is defined by the near complete absence of cerebellar tissue with only remnants of the anterior vermis, flocculus, and/or middle cerebellar peduncles. [HPO:probinson, PMID:20305277, PMID:26331051]
An elevated concentration of lactate in the caudate nucleus. This finding can be elicited by magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23810640]
Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve. [HPO:probinson]

A testis that is located at the upper scrotum or lower inguinal canal and that can be made to descend completely into the scrotum without resistance by manual reduction but returns to its original position by the cremasteric reflex. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23061004, PMID:4380054]
An abnormal reduction in the inflammatory response to injury or infection. [MONARCH:mhaendel]
A severe form of gait ataxia such that an affected person cannot walk at all. [HPO:probinson]
Asthma attacks following exercise. [HPO:probinson]
Severe asthma unresponsive to repeated courses of beta-agonist therapy such as inhaled albuterol, levalbuterol, or subcutaneous epinephrine. [HPO:probinson, PMID:22794687]
Increased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). [Monarch:mhaendel]
Decreased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). [Monarch:mhaendel]
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the prefrontal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23585882]
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the thalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the hypothalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan. [HPO:probinson]
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the parietal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan. [HPO:probinson, PMID:15073255]

Phenotype: Mildly reduced left ventricular ejection fraction
Def: A small reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle. The normal range in adults is at least 50 percent, and a mild reduction is defined as 40-49 percent. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16376782, PMID:27206819]

Phenotype: Moderately reduced left ventricular ejection fraction
Def: A medium reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle, defined as a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30-39 percent. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16376782, PMID:27206819, PMID:29083812]

Phenotype: Severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction
Def: A large reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle. The normal range in adults is at over 50 percent, and a severe reduction is defined as less than 30 percent. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16376782, PMID:27206819, PMID:29083812]

Phenotype: Regional left ventricular wall motion abnormality
Def: An abnormal motion of a segment of the left ventricle during the cardiac cycle. [HPO:probinson]
An exaggerated response to carotid sinus baroreceptor stimulation resulting in syncope from transient diminished cerebral perfusion. [HPO:probinson]
Syncope following a quick change in position from lying down to standing. [HPO:probinson]
Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency. [HPO:probinson, PMID:16030444, UToronto:HTrang]
Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking. [HPO:probinson]
A failure to develop of the upper vagina. [HPO:probinson]
A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina. [HPO:probinson]
An anomalous build up of copper (Cu) in the brain. [HPO:probinson]
An anomalous build up of iron (Fe) in the substantia nigra. [HPO:probinson]

An increase in the distance between vertebral pedicles, which are the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the vertebral body, at the junction of its posterior and lateral surfaces. [UToronto:htrang]
Accumulation of calcium salts in the pineal gland. [HPO:probinson]
A glial uniloculated or multiloculated fluid-filled sac that either reside within or completely replace the pineal gland. [HPO:probinson, PMID:21801982]
An abnormal reduction in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland. [PMID:24456088, UToronto:htrang]
An abnormal elevation in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland. [UToronto:htrang]
Failure to develop of the pineal gland, defined clinically as the absence of the pineal gland with no indication of the pineal gland even having been present. [UToronto:htrang]

An anomaly in the amount or timing of melatonin secretion by the pineal gland. Note that melatonin is also synthesized by multiple tissues outside of the pineal gland. [PMID:22724080, UToronto:htrang]
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire thalamus. [HPO:probinson]
